title: famous harry potter trolley platform
story: :root Famous Harry Potter trolley from Platform  and   is going on tour - how to see itHead on over to these four city train stations to grab a photo with the iconic Harry Potter trolley at Platform  and   with the iconic trolley Harry Potter Platform  ¾ trolley at Kings Cross Station" content"https:i-prod.dailyrecord incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _image-jpeg.jpg" width"" "" Fans can grab a photowith the iconic trolley Image: Wizarding WorldByEmily ChudyBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Sep | commentsThe famous trolley from Platform  and   is a much-loved tourist attraction that resides at Londonaposs Kings Cross station. But Harry Potter fans wonapost need to travel to the city to visit the popular prop, as one is set to go on tour around the UK.A replica of the trolley is set to visit several train stations across the UK in honour the th anniversary of the first wizarding film - Harry Potter and The Philosopheraposs Stone, our sister site Chill reports. From October - Potterheads can visit the following cities and snap a photo with their house scarf for social media: Edinburgh Waverley Station , Birmingham New Street Station , Cardf Central Station , Belfast Lanyon Place Station .Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter. Stuart Kirkwood, group property director from Network Rail, said: “The Platform  ¾ trolley in King’s Cross station is a fantastic attraction that boasts huge queues of Harry Potter fans daily. It’s been great to take this fan favourite to locations outside of London to celebrate the th anniversary of the film. “We’re extremely pleased to add this touch of magic to these stations.” As with the London Kings Cross trolley, visiting the attraction and taking your own photos is free, however you will have to pay to purchase an iconic house scarf picture taken by a professional photographer. news uk-news fuel-shortages-arent-widespread-just-"Bristol: Journalist helps man push his car into petrol stationByMichael HoldenGuy FaulconbridgeMilo Boyd:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsJust one per cent of the countryaposs petrol stations are closed due to lack of fuel, it has been reported. Up and down the UK drivers have been resisting government calls not to panic by heading out to their local garage for a tank top-up. Fearful that disrupted supply lines will leave them unable to fill up, many motorists have been stuck in long queues for hours, battling those others who had a similar idea. Industry professionals have said that while the queues may look dramatic, there is not too much cause for concern when it comes to actual petrol supply. Less than  of the , filling stations in the UK have been forced to close, the Daily Mail reports. What do you think of the panic buyers  Have your say in the comments  Around  BP garages have shut completely and a maximum of  have run out of at least one type of fuel. A apossmall numberapos of Tesco refilling stations have also been impacted, said Esso owner ExxonMobil, which runs the sites. President of the AA Edmund King reiterated on Saturday that there is plenty of fuel at the source and no need to stock up. The good news is you can only really fill up once - youaposve got to use the fuel, so this should be a short-term thing, he told BBC Breakfast. Itaposs not like the fuel crises in the past when the supplier was hit by strikes, etc. So, once people have filled up, they wonapost travel more than they normally travel, so this strain on the system should ease up in the next few days. Concerns about petrol supplies were triggered by supply chain issues caused, in part, by the shortage of heavy goods vehicledrivers. In a bid to fill some of the vacancies caused, in no small part, by Brexit, the government is planning to offer short term visas for EU drivers.  Weaposre looking at temporary measures to avoid any immediate problems, but any measures we introduce will be very strictly time limited, a spokeswoman for Johnsonaposs Downing Street office said in a statement. Like countries around the world we are suffering from a temporary Covid-related shortage of drivers needed to move supplies around the country. The UKaposs Road Haulage Associationsays Britain is facing a shortage of some , drivers, a result of workers leaving the industry, Brexit and Covid-, which put a stop to driver training and testing for about a year. WARNING: The following embedded tweets contain strong language some may find offensiveThe government is reportedly considering granting entry to up to , foreign drivers into Britain on short-term visas, a measure that logistics companies and retailers have demanded for months but which the government had previously ruled out. Brian Madderson, the chairman of the Petrol Retailers Association which represents independent fuel retailers, said he expected the problem to continue for a while longer. I think this situation is going to get worse before it gets better, he told Sky News. EG Group, which runs  forecourts across Britain, said on Friday it would impose a purchase limit of  poundsper customer for fuel due to the unprecedented customer demand. From early on Saturday, motorists began queuing outside filling stations and some forecourts closed as fuel ran out.  I was out on my bike ... and came past my BP garage and it was chaos, Merriman said. As soon as the message gets out there might be a fuel shortage, people understandably react. Police across the country reported congestion caused by motorists waiting in line, and urged people not to contact them about the problems the traffic was causing. Britain, the worldaposs fth-largest economy, is also grappling with a spike in Europe  an natural gas costs causing soaring energy prices and a potential food supply crunch. At least one bust-up has broken out on the countryaposs forecourts, as a clash broke out at a busy petrol station in Portsmouth, Hants, where drivers had flocked to a Shell station. Two groups of men were aposscreamingapos at each other before one group chased another fleeing in a van - hurling stones at the vehicle, according to a witness. The ugly scenes shocked onlookers at a forecourt in the Hilsea area of the city at around .am. A witness said: People were queuing throughout the night. Pumps are almost dry. title: girl 15 helps brave little
story: :root Girl, , helps brave little sister win latest cancer fight by donating bone marrowMaisie Bullock was given a helping hand in her latest battle with leukaemia after being diagnosed just before the pandemic struck - by her older sister CecilyMaisie and Cecily with Fearne Cotton Image: Elizabeth KeatesByEmma Pryer:,  Sep | commentsLeukaemia patient Maisie Bullock and fellow cancer survivors couldn’t have chosen a better song as they celebrated triumph over adversity at a charity gala. This Is Me, Keala Settle’s stirring and emotional classic from The Greatest Showman, includes the lyrics “I know that there’s a place for us, For we are glorious”. And glorious they were as TV stars Fearne Cotton and Kirsty Gallacher looked on in support and admiration. But for Maisie, a very special member of the audience was sister Cecily, . She donated the bone marrow which helped Maisie thrive and overcome the latest cancer onslaught. Having fought the disease since she was seven, Maisie was struck again just before the pandemic hit. And Cecily would be the key to winning this phase of the challenge. Now , Maisie says: “Cecily did an amazing thing. When I found out I had relapsed, that was really tough. But there is more to le than cancer. I try to have a positive attitude and take one day at a time.” Cecily was nervous about the procedure and admits: “I didn’t enjoy it but, of course, I would do it because it was for my sister.” Maisie, from Northampton, is in remission and the sisters hope their story will help raise money during Childhood Cancer Awareness month – as well as spread the message that cancer doesn’t have to define anyone. The London gala for charity Young Lives vs Cancer helped raise £,. Maisie brought the house down with a speech and group performance of This Is Me.TV and radio star Fearne, , was so moved she posted a message on Instagram, saying: “The best bit of the night for me was watching a young lady called Maisie sing for us alongside some other young people who have had cancer.They hadn’t rehearsed in person, only over Zoom, but they totally smashed it.” Maisie says: “She was so lovely, really friendly and down to earth. “She told me I was a great singer – coming from her, that felt amazing!” Young Lives vs Cancer has offered great support – providing somewhere to stay for Maisie’s parents as the youngster twice had gruelling two-month bouts of chemotherapy. The charity also enlisted another group to enable Maisie to attend school remotely via a remarkable AI robot that sat in her classroom seat. It allowed her to keep up to speed with lessons and speak to pals at break times. It was back in January  that parents Sarah, , and Pete, , were told Maisie had leukaemia. She had complained of an aching shoulder and stomach pains. Sarah says: “Maisie was a typical fit, healthy seven-year-old. I was expecting to be told she needed appendix surgery. Instead they told us she had leukaemia. “It just didn’t make sense at all.”  There was no time to waste and the family was told a waiting ambulance would take Maisie from their local Northampton General Hospital to a specialist ward at Queen’s Medical Centre in Nottingham,  miles away. Two months of chemo began and the parents were placed in Home-From-Home accommodation just a stone’s throw away. Cecily stayed with grandparents and visited when possible. Sarah – who, like husband Pete, works in human resources – goes on: “It was terrying and frightening. We were completely sleep-deprived and entering this whole new world we’d never imagined being part of. We were told it was serious but treatable. But she was very poorly with a low immune system. The hardest day was when she had to get measured for a wheelchair and a wig. “Those were two of the most shocking things. As it happens we didn’t need the wheelchair and it was eight months before her hair came out – and Maisie took everything in her stride. We’d say, ‘It’s fine. We’ve just got to get through this rubbish bit’.” After two months the remaining treatment was mainly managed at home.  Chemo was administered by nurses, through a Hickman line in her chest. She ed to school, though even a mild temperature would put her back in hospital for four days at a time. Maisie’s treatment finally finished in the summer of . But by the end of  she started complaining of leg pain. Shortly before Christmas, almost four years since her first diagnosis, Maisie relapsed. Her leukaemia had ed. On New Year’s Eve she began another two-month round of chemo back in Nottingham. “It was that awful sense of deja vu,” Sarah says. “But we did it the first time and we would do it again.” This time doctors said Maisie would also need a stem cell transplant to stop the leukaemia from ing. Cecily had a one in four chance of being a match.  Her apprehension was understandable. Cecily said: “I have never stayed in hospital or had an operation before, so I didn’t really want to do it but I couldn’t not, so I sucked it up and went ahead.” It was March  – the week of the first lockdown – when Maisie, Cecily and Sarah headed to London’s Great Ormond Street Hospital after isolating for weeks together to avoid Cecily getting sick. Sarah says: “I called our consultant and said, ‘Are you sure this is the best time to wipe out a child’s immune system – heading into a pandemic  He told me we didn’t have a choice. Which kind of helped because we just had to press on.” Cecily had bone marrow extracted on April  and watched through a hospital window as the stem cells were delivered into Maisie’s bloodstream. Cecily says: “It was surreal.” For two months Sarah and Maisie stayed in the ward, with mum venturing outside once a week for six minutes to receive fresh clothes from Pete. Maisie and her mum whiled away the hours on TikTok, family quizzes and singing. Sarah adds: “We’d literally cross off the days in that room. The nurses were amazing but it did feel a bit like prison.” Get the latest news straight to your inbox with our daily newsletter One day, she filmed Maisie’s rendition of Rise Up – Andra Day’s hit that became a message of hope for people facing tough times. On that note, the gala was a signicant milestone – and helping the charity is important to the family. Sarah says: “Maisie has been unlucky to be very ill but that’s just a small part of who she is and just a small part of who we are as a family. So many people travel long distances for treatment and that’s why support of Young Lives vs Cancer is so vital. It’s so much harder to cope, and these families have enough to cope with already, so they need that support.” Meanwhile, Maisie hasn’t made a huge fuss about things. And of Cecily, while realising they now share an extra-special bond, she says: “I guess we’re like a lot of sisters – good friends with a few arguments along the way!” And Sarah adds: “Maisie’s enormously resilient and doesn’t think anything bad has ever happened to her. Our children are so much more than their cancer.” For more information or cancer support, visit younglivesvscancer.org.uk Comment MORE ON Kirsty GallacherFearne CottonThis Is MeGreat Ormond Street HospitalNew YearThe Greatest ShowmanHospitalsImmune systemCancerLeukaemia" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news gp-explains-brits-having-worst-"Why does it feel like Im having the worst cold ever  A GP ExplainsByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA GP has explained why Brits are suffering with severe bouts of the common cold this autumn. Thousands of people Brits are reporting symptoms that could be easily mistaken for Covid. Negative results show they are suffering instead with a harmless but nasty common cold infection.Dr Philippa Kaye, a GP at a London practice, told BBC Newsbeat : Weaposve actually been seeing a rise in the number of coughs and colds and viral infections.We are mixing in a way that we havenapost been mixing over the past  months. The spike in viral infections come as the public s to normality -with less stress now on mask wearing and social distancing as Brits head back to work or school. New arrivals at universities also face a spike in Fresheraposs Flu - an increase in viral symptoms as students bring viruses from their own towns to their lecture halls, Wales Online reports.Rebecca London, , from Bournemouth told the BBC she caught a cold at a festival and it was aposthe worst everapos. She said: I barely slept, Iaposd wake up in the night just coughing, a constantly runny nose and feeling so tired. The cold lasted more than a week, she said. Noor Hashmi, , another student, told the BBC: Normally Iaposm still able to go about my day, but this one left me with muscle fatigue, a lost voice and headache that meant Iaposve just stayed indoors. Dr Philippa advises people experiencing symptoms of Covid - like a new cough, fever, loss of sense of taste or smell - to take a PCR test. Cold symptoms can be treated with rest, fluids and over-the-counter painkillers, she adds. Following Covid prevention measures - like wearing masks and social distancing - means weaposve missed the chance to develop immunity to coughs, cold and flu viruses for two years. As your body has not had the opportunity to fight the illnesses, when they reach you the symptoms can be worse.Dr Ron Eccles, Emeritus Professor at Cardf Universityaposs School of Biosciences told Patient.info : If youaposve been exposed to a particular virus before, you may not develop any symptoms at all, because your immune system has been primed to fight off the infection.Itaposs the same process that means you usually only catch chickenpox once. With common colds we generally donapost have such a strong immune response and therefore we probably donapost get lelong immunity to a particular virus, he adds. However, we may get a milder responsewe are exposed to that virus again. The NHSaposs big three symptoms for Covid are a high temperature which leaves your back or chest feeling hot, a new, continuous cough, and a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste. If you experience any of these symptoms then get a PCR test and self-isolate until you get your test result. title: heroic stories london marathon runners
story: :root Exclusive: Heroic stories of London Marathon runners - from paralysed horse rider to lesaver dadClaire Lomas, who was awarded an MBE in  and was one of just  people to be given a Spirit of London Award, guaranteeing her place in this year’s Marathon, is determined to take home a medalClaire Lomas is determined to win a medalByEmma PryerMatthew Barbour:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsOver the past  years, the London Marathon has attracted thousands of runners and raised thousands for charity. Here, some of next Sunday’s inspiring competitors reveal why it’s such a cherished race for them… This time, I want to get a medal In , Claire Lomas won fans across the world when she completed the London Marathon after  days. The former horse rider, who was paralysed from the chest down in a riding accident in , wore a robotic suit to take part in the race, raising £, for Spinal Research. But this year, Claire – who was awarded an MBE in  and was one of just  people to be given a Spirit of London Award, guaranteeing her place in this year’s Marathon – is determined to take home a medal.  The -year-old will be competing in motorcycle gear to raise money for Whizz-Kidz, a charity that transforms the lives of disabled youths. Claire, who lives in Melton Mowbray, Leics, said: “I am hoping to complete it in a day but it’s going to be tough. “My husband Dan and friend Stuart will be accompanying me as my grid girls complete with heels, dresses and wigs.” To sponsor Claire, text CLAIRELM £ to . Iaposve loved training alongside my DNA twin When Vicky Lawrence and Elliott Brock cross the finish line at the London Marathon, few spectators will know the bond the two runners have. In , physiotherapist Elliott, , donated his bone marrow to save Vicky’s le after the eight-year- old was diagnosed with severe aplastic anaemia.  At the time of the le-saving op, in Vicky’s home town of Birmingham, the pair were complete strangers. Vicky’s family wrote numerous letters to Elliott to say how grateful they were, but it wasn’t until Vicky started studying for her A-levels that he finally replied and they became firm friends. Vicky, who is now  and a third-year medical student at Newcastle University, first suggested they take on the London Marathon to raise money for Anthony Nolan UK two years ago.  Dad-of-two Elliott, who lives in Colchester, Essex, said: “I foolishly agreed, but have loved the training and can’t wait to run alongside my DNA twin. “There’s something poetic about Vicky getting me off my backside and healthy after I saved her le all those years ago.”To sponsor Vicky and Elliott, go to justgiving fundraising victoria-lawrence Iaposm doing it for Wilma Nicknamed Iron Man, Andy Farrer really is a hero who has superhuman strength. The -year-old runs marathons carrying an ironing board and iron in tribute to his late partner Wilma Patton-Brolly, who took her own le in , aged . The pair, who met on a blind date in , enjoyed a quirky pastime called “extreme ironing”, in which they posed for photos in scenic locations with an ironing board.  Andy was planning to propose to Wilma at the finish line of the London Marathon in . Instead, he now spends his time raising awareness of suicide prevention. Andy, who never trains for his runs and cracks open a beer on the starting line, already holds the Guinness World Record for doing the London Marathon while carrying an ironing board and iron – and is keen to repeat it. Since he started running, the Sainsbury’s meat counter worker has raised around £, for charity and is aiming to raise £, for VICTA next weekend.  Andy, from Portrush in Northern Ireland, said: “If you’re holding an ironing board, people ask questions. I can talk about mental health, suicide and the Samaritans. “If I can help other families avoid the suffering we’ve had, that’s my goal.”To support Andy visit uk.virginmoneygiving andyfarrer My daughter ran race before she was even born Lillie Clibbon-Grant has already run the London Marathon – despite having never competed before – as her mother ran it in , unaware she was two-and-a-half weeks pregnant. Lara Grant was so surprised by her “midle baby” that she wrote to race sponsors Flora once Lillie was born to ask for a medal for her newborn. When they posted one, they also invited Lillie to take part as soon as she was old enough, in  – and now the -year-old is doing just that. Flora also arranged for three-time London Marathon winner Paula Radclfe to help Lillie out by giving her some training tips via Zoom. Catering manager Lara, , from Reading, Berks, jokes that Lillie “must have been the race’s youngest competitor”. But Lillie, who is raising money for Newbury charity Time to Talk, said: “It inspired me to get into sport. I’m excited to be running. I hope I do Mum proud.”Flora’s Get Towns Active Campaign arranged for marathon veteran Paula Radclfe to surprise Lillie. For more details, see flora or #TeamFlora on Instagram.Comment MORE ON SainsburysSamaritansNewcastle UniversityPaula RadclfeKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeLondon MarathonIron ManCharitiesPregnancyRoyal FamilyMental healthWorld recordsLondon Marathon raceSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how hot your town like
story: :root How hot does your town like it  The nations spice preferences revealed... Are you a heat-loving West Midlander  Or perhaps a more chilli-wary east of England resident  Our survey reveals which areas in the UK are partial to a bit of spiceAbstract luxury soft Red background Christmas Valentines layout design,studio,room, web template ,Business report with smooth circle gradient colorAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  We all know that KFC ’s Popcorn Chicken is practically a national treasure – crunchy, moreish, delicious little pops of  per cent chicken breast – but here’s some news: IT JUST GOT SPICY. For a limited time, it’s acquired an edge, a kick, a fiery twist to tantalise your tastebuds. Introducing the Zinger Popcorn Bucket.Trialled in ten lucky locations in April, it proved so popular it’s now officially launching across the UK, so that everyone can feel the burn! But where are the spice fiends who’ll be going straight off to order it, and which of us Brits are more chary with the chilli  SPICE UP YOUR LIFE KFC surveyed the nation’s spice preferences, asking residents in Northern Ireland, Wales, Scotland, London, the North East, North West, Yorkshire, East Midlands, West Midlands, East of England, South East and South West how spicy they like their food. The results show that it’s Londoners who have the biggest appetite for heat:  per cent of those in the capital said they like their food to be nice and spicy or even to feel their mouths on fire. The Scots and West Midlanders are runners-up in their love of the burn, at  and  per cent respectively. But spice is off the menu in Yorkshire: around one in five people declared that they prefer their food mild – the highest number of any region surveyed. Hot on their heelswere those in the East of England. The survey also revealed the gap between people’s estimation of their own region’s appetite for spice and the reality. Residents of Northern Ireland were widest off the mark, guessing that only  per cent would like fiery food, whereas the true figure was  per cent. In contrast,  per cent of those in the North West thought their population would love serious spice, but it was actually a mere  per cent. London and the West Midlands came out top when people were asked which region they thought would have the greatest penchant for spicy food, and they were broadly right. But those in the South West were wrongly assumed to have the least tolerance for the tingle factor. And what about you  Can you take the heat  If you’re a dance-till-dawn, touch-of-the-hedonist kind of person who loves food that makes your eyes widen and your tongue take notice, the Zinger Popcorn Bucket is your order of dreams. If you get your kicks from breaking in your new lambswool slippers in front of Call the Midwe, and your flavour frisson comes from a sprinkling of parsley... maybe not so much. The Zinger Popcorn Bucket is only here until October , so now’s the time to find outyou can handle the heat!Download the app, head in store or order online. news uk-news huge-queues-form-hundreds-line-"Lincolnshire: Hundreds queue at garden centre to see SantaByLucy Marshall:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsHundreds of people queued to meet Father Christmas months before the big day. Customers flocked to the Brigg Garden Centre in Lincolnshire to meet the man himself at an unseasonal winter wonderland on Saturday.From Christmas trees, lights, gts, and even Santa-inspired crockery baskets, people have been filling their trollies with heaps of decorations, Hull Daily Mail reported. One staff member said that the car park was packed from am. Do you think September  is an appropriate date to start preparing for Christmas  Tell us in the comments below.  Staff had to put out metal barriers for people to form an orderly queue outside at around noon. All this excitement came despite Christmas being  days away - a full quarter of a year. Mr and Mrs Claus were seen walking around the store greeting customers and handing out sweets.  There was also a performer singing Christmas songs as customers browsed. Speaking about starting off the festive season, organiser Amy Stubbs said: We are all so excited for this festive season. Christmas is our favourite time of year here in Brigg Garden Centre - it is a truly spectacular experience and you donapost want to miss it. There will also be a Santaaposs Grotto event coming to the centre in the run up to Christmas. news uk-news im-celeb-people-baffled-how-"It Confused Ant  Dec But How Would You Pronounce It ByMillie ReevesBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Sep | comments‘Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch’ is perhaps the most famous Welsh village name, but it’s not the only one that non-Welsh speakers struggle with. Presenting duo Ant and Dec have left people making all kinds of attempts to pronounce another location after snapping a photo on their way to the I’m a Celeb filming spot.The pair once struggled to pronounce Gwrych Castle, which is near Abergele, where the show was filmed last year, Chill reports.And en route to the venue where the show will be filmed for , the presenters stopped off at Mynyddislwyn, which left UK fans pondering the correct pronunciation. Even Ant and Dec looked baffled - but that may be because they were  miles out of their way after taking a wrong turn at Newport.  So here’s all you - and Ant and Dec - need to know about Mynyddislwyn and how to pronounce it like a local with a quick Welsh lesson.How do you say it Don’t stumble at the first hurdle - the ‘y’ in the first part of the word. It’s pronounced like aposughapos. aposDdapos in Welsh is classed as its own letter and is pronounced aposthapos. Another confusion comes with aposwyapos that makes an aposooapos. But let’s make it easy for you - put it all together and you get mun-ith-is-loo-in.Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter.What does it mean anyway Mynydd means mountain in Welsh and the parish is often translated as aposmountain ashapos or aposmountain below the groveapos. There is actually a place called Mountain Ash not too far away, so donapost get them mixed up.Where is it exactly Mynyddislwyn is a small parish between Ystrad Mynach and Crumlin and while technically in Monmouthshire, itaposs more aligned to Caerphilly. So people there claim it as theirs, whatever the internet might say.And what about Gwrych Castle  Any help on how to say that According to researcher at Gwrych Castle Preservation Trust, Rhŷn Williams, the impressive Welsh castle is in fact pronounced, Goo-rreech. He said the stress on the aposWapos part is paramount. *That’s ‘welcome back’ in Welsh! news uk-news inside-britains-biggest-family-radfords-"The Radford family give an insight into their family leByRyan MerrieldReporterLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsMum-of- Sue Radford has afforded fans an in-depth tour of her familyaposs swanky garden, complete with an outdoor bar and hot tub. The family live in a -bed former care home over four floors in Morecambe, Lancashire, and often update their followers with videos on YouTube. In the latest offering, Sue, , started by showing off the childrenaposs play area at the front of the mega property which has swings and a slide. Itaposs also where the kids store their bikes, and the family hopes to soon buy a plastic storage facility to put them in, she explained. I think thataposs going to be next on the to do list, the busy mum - who runs a bakery alongside husband Noel,  - told the camera. Sue then walked across the articial lawn in the back garden where the family boasts a collection of luxurious sun loungers, a hot tub, fire pit and bar and adjoining seating area. She said they are planning to buy a gazebo to put the hot tub in so they can continue to enjoy it now that autumn has arrived. I have to say [the hot tub] has just been the best thing ever, admitted Sue. The kids all get so much enjoyment out of that.  Sue and Noel - who famously donapost rely on any benefits to support their brood - currently have  of their kids living under their roof, with many sharing bedrooms. The two oldest - Chris, , and Sophie,  - have previously flown the nest. Their th child, Alfie, was sadly stillborn in .  Pointing to the grey seating area with scatter cushions, the mum said: I just love this area, itaposs so nice. You can sit here with a nice cup of coffee in the evening and just chill out when the kids have gone to bed. But her favourite spot is the bar. This is probably one of my most favourite things in the garden along with the hot tub. Itaposs just brilliant, said Sue.  In a previous video last year, Noel had explained how he had built it with the help of daughter Chloe, , and son James, , during the Covid lockdown. Itaposs just been so brilliant. We just love it, gushed Sue. Nicknamed aposThe Lockdown Barapos, it has been decorated with a wind chime and signs, including one that says: I wine because they wine!  They also have a barbecue and pizza oven for outdoor dinners. Sue explained: This was Aldiaposs pizza oven and it is really really good. Weaposve had so many nights with the kids making their own pizzas and things so thataposs been a massive hit. Earlier this year, Sue and Noel began a major DIY project, in which they transformed their garden, including adding an articial lawn which they vacuum to keep clean. news uk-news kate-middleton-dons-tennis-gear-"Kate Middleton meets Emma RaducanuByJenner Newton:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge has met with teenage tennis sensation Emma Raducanu to congratulate her on her stunning US Open win - and got competitive by going up against her on court.The -year-old met with Kate Middleton at the Lawn Tennis Associationaposs National Tennis Centre in London, where they teamed up for a doubles game before going head-to-head against each other.And it was even remarked that it was getting competitive.Kate came dressed for the occasion in a navy tennis skirt and tracksuit top and also brought her racket along with her. As well as meeting Emma, Kate also chatted with fellow British US Open champions Joe Salisbury, who won the menaposs doubles title with American Rajeev Ram, and Gordon Reid and Alfie Hewett, the menaposs wheelchair doubles champions. There was an awkward moment when Kate first arrived as she was unsure how to congratulate the group.She said: Are we shaking hands  I donapost want to break your training bubbles.Itaposs really awkward, you donapost know quite whether to do it. It is the same with face masks.You never know whether to hug people, congratulate them or shake hands. But amazing, guys honestly, congratulations.Emma, who is now ranked nd in the world, became the first qualier to win one of the four majors when she claimed the US Open womenaposs singles title earlier this month. She also became the first British woman in  years to win a Grand Slam title, when she breezed past Canadian Leylah Fernandez in straight sets.After her victory, Kate took to Twitter to send a rare personal tweet saying : Huge congratulations @EmmaRaducanu on your stunning performances and historic Grand Slam victory! Incredible –we are all so proud of you. @leylahfernandez well done on your amazing achievements at this year’s #USOpen, it’s been a pleasure to watch. CThe Queen also said it was a remarkable achievement at such a young age and added she was an inspiration for future tennis players. In a personal message to Emma, she said: I send my congratulations to you on your success in winning the United States Open Tennis Championships. It is a remarkable achievement at such a young age, and is testament to your hard work and dedication. I have no doubt your outstanding performance, and that of your opponent Leylah Fernandez, will inspire the next generation of tennis players. Raducanu shot into the spotlight with a surprise y run to the second week of Wimbledon - her Grand Slam debut tournament earlier this summer. And even before the tournament, it appears that Kate and husband Prince William were fans of the young Brit. In a tweet from July, the couple made their predictions of who would win Wimbledon and said: Unbiased prediction to win it: @andy_murray and @EmmaRaducanu #Wimbledon. title: kids young 5 offered grief
story: :root Sabina Nessa: Kids as young as  offered grief support after tragic murder of teacherYear Two pupils are devastated by death of their beloved teacher Sabina Nessa who was described as kind, caring and absolutely dedicated to her pupilsTragic Sabina was a popular primary school teacher Image: politan PoliceByDaniel OMahony:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep Children as young as five are being offered psychological support after the killing of their teacher Sabina Nessa. The “brilliant” -year-old had taken over a Year One class only shortly before her murder nine days ago. Lisa Williams, headteacher at Rushey Green Primary School in Lewisham, south London, said all the pupils and staff were devastated. She added: “Sabina was a brilliant teacher. She was kind, caring and absolutely dedicated to her pupils.” Sabina’s body was found in Cator Park, near her home in Kidbrooke, south east London, after she failed to arrive for a Friday night date at a pub. Yesterday a child’s white T-shirt with the message, “Thank you for being my teacher” hand-written in felt-tip pen was among tributes left at the park.  It is understood Ms Williams visited each class to talk to pupils, with educational psychologists also offering help. The Duchess of Cambridge yesterday spoke of her grief for Sabina on her official Twitter feed. She wrote: “I am saddened by the loss of another innocent young woman on our streets. My thoughts are with Sabina’s family and friends.”  An unnamed teacher at the -pupil school told a local newspaper: “It’s hard for teachers to reassure children while they are themselves consumed with grief. “The Year Two pupils who she had last year in Year One will be the most upset – and their parents.” Sabina, from Bedfordshire, studied at the University of Greenwich before completing her PGCE teacher training last year at her local university. Her colleague, one of  staff at the school, said: “The first anyone knew was when we arrived on Monday.  “It’s awful enough when someone dies – this is so much worse. It’s impossible to comprehend. We were sitting beside her on Friday… then this.” Police yesterday searched drains near to where Sabina died and also want to trace a balding man seen close by at the time on CCTV. Revealing he was holding a “red reflective item”, they said they are keeping an open mind as to whether it may have been used in her murder. Det Chief Insp Neil John said: “People may recall this man carrying a red reflective object, and possibly trying to conceal it up his sleeve.” On Friday night hundreds of mourners, including parents and pupils from Sabina’s school, gathered for a candlelight vigil in her memory.  Her sister, Jebina Yasmin Islam, broke down in tears as she told them: “I’ve lost my caring, beautul sister.” Sabina’s death has sparked fresh anger over women’s safety, six months after the murder of Sarah Everard, , by Met police officer Wayne Couzens.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Kate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeEducationMurderSchools" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news meghan-markle-gives-first-update-"Princess Diana’s brother genuinely looking forward to meeting LilibetByJenner Newton:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsMeghan Markle has given her first update on baby Lilibet, describing her little daughter as beautul. Meghan and husband Prince Harry in New York for a number of official engagements, their first public trip since quitting the UK for Calornia and stepping down as senior royals. Yesterday, they made a series of appearances around New York City and met with political figures, including the New York mayor Bill de Blasio and the US ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield. Harry and Meghan have made the trip to the city alone and are thought to have left three-month-old Lilibet and her big brother Archie at home in Calornia. Since Lilibetaposs birth in July, the couple have not released any images of the youngster and have hardly given any updates about her.But as they walked between engagements yesterday, one reporter from Inside Edition called out to the couple, asking: Meghan, howaposs Lilibet And Meghan simply replied: Sheaposs beautul. Another also asked: Howaposs Archie , to which Meghan gave a big thumbs up. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .The coupleaposs tour of New York continues today with Meghan appearing at a school in Harlem, where she read the young pupils her book The Bench. Yesterday marked Meghanaposs first public appearance since the birth of Lilibet when she and Harry visited the cityaposs highest building - the One World Trade Center, built on the site of the former World Trade Center, and its One World Observatory. As they posed for pictures on the observation deck, Meghan was askedshe was enjoying her visit to New York and she replied: Itaposs wonderful to be back, thank you. Once the meeting was over, Harry and Meghan clutched each otheraposs hands as they walked to the   Memorial nearby.Later they met with the US ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, who later wrote on Twitter that they had an “important discussion” that included the pandemic, racial justice and raising awareness of mental health. Tomorrow, the couple will appear at the -hour star-studded global TV event Global Citizen Live in Central Park. At the event, they will continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the Covid- pandemic for everyone, everywhere. The event organisers call them two of the strongest voices on vaccine equity. title: meghan markle shocked prince harry
story: :root Meghan Markle shocked Prince Harry by happily peeing in woods on first holidayPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are in New York for their first trip to the Big Apple together - but their first-ever trip abroad with one another to Botswana in  was a very dferent one altogether Image: Getty ImagesByJenner Newton:,  Sep | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are currently enjoying their first-ever trip to New York together for their first public events since stepping back as senior royals. Theyaposve already visited the One World Observatory, the   Museum and attended a meeting with the cityaposs mayor, where Meghan said: It is wonderful to be back. But the trip is a far cry from their first-ever time travelling together shortly after they started dating in , when they visited Botswana. Using the trip as a chance to get to know one another, Meghan and Harry spent five nights away from their luxury log cabin in the wilderness to camp alone. And according to the coupleaposs unofficial biography Finding Freedom, Harry was delightfully surprised by how down-to-earth Meghan was when it came to roughing it for the week. Meghan reportedly packed very little clothing and cleaned her face with baby wipes and happily wandered into the woodlandsshe needed a bathroom break, the book claims. Harry and Meghan are said to have bonded over their love of nature during the trip, and the pair ed a year later after getting engaged to work with elephant conservation groups.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. A friend of the couple told the bookaposs authors: The fact that theyaposre both as happy just throwing on a backpack and going out to explore...I honestly think these experiences will never stop for them. The coupleaposs trip to New York continues today with the pair set to appear at the Global Citizen Live event in Central Park. At the event, they will continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the COVID- pandemic for everyone, everywhere. The event organisers call them two of the strongest voices on vaccine equity. The couple has also previously written an open letter to the chief executives of pharmaceutical companies like Pfizer, Moderna and AstraZeneca urging them to redouble their support for the UN-sponsored Covax vaccine equity programme. The trip to New York comes after the couple was named in TIME magazineaposs  most influential people in  last week. The magazine praised the pair for having compassion for the people they donapost know, and added: They donapost just opine. They run towards the struggle. title: most common symptom tell difference
story: :root Most common symptom to tell the dference between Covid and a coldSymptoms of the Covid- virus are extremely similar to those of a regular cold, particularly for those who have been double jabbed.A crossover of symptoms makes it dficult to tell the dference between a cold and Covid- Image: Getty ImagesBySophie LawAdvance Content Writer:,  Sep | commentsIn a bid to help people distinguish between coronavirus and a common cold, scientists have revealed the ‘one’ symptom that sets the two apart. Experts have warned of a crossover of symptoms for the past  months, making it dficult to tell the dference between the two illnesses. Symptoms of the virus are extremely similar to those of a regular cold, particularly for those who have been double jabbed.Vaccinated people who contract the virus are likely to experience a runny nose, sore throat and sneezing, the Daily Record reported. But now, new research from the ZOE Covid Symptom study, developed by Kingaposs College London, has found that thereaposs one symptom that can help tell the dference.Data shows that loss of smellor loss of taste is still one of the most important predictors of testing positive for coronavirus rather than a regular cold.Researchers say you can check your sense of smell easily at home by snfing scented foods or products, or noticing whether familiar foods start to lose their flavour or taste strange. Millions of people have been logging their symptoms, tests and vaccines on the UK ZOE COVID Symptom Study app since it was launched. Thanks to health reports, scientists now know there are more than  symptoms of Covid-, including headache, runny nose, sneezing and sore throat. Common Covid symptoms in people fully vaccinated Data as of September : Runny nose Headache Sneezing Sore throat Loss of smellCommon COVID- symptomsyou’re unvaccinated Headache Runny Nose Sore Throat Fever Persistent cough Loss of smellcomes further down the list for unvaccinated people, but it’s still an important predictor of having COVID- rather than a regular cold. title: new mr england says nightmare
story: :root Exclusive: New Mr England says nightmare drink-drive prison sentence made him change his waysLiam Royce Ulla got six months after crashing his car into four other vehicles and a wall while trying to escape police in . He jumped from his Audi A and fled on foot, but was caught by DNA left on the airbagLiam Royce Ulla has been crowned Mr EnglandByPhil CardySenior reporter:,  Sep | commentsThe newly crowned Mr ­England has told how a nightmare spell in prison turned his le around. Liam Royce Ulla – who will now take part in the Mr World contest – got six months after crashing his car into four other vehicles and a wall while trying to escape police in . He jumped from his Audi A and fled on foot, but was caught by DNA left on the airbag. Liam said: “I was  and drinking too much. I was a daft young man. “I was on an -month driving ban but I left a club and got behind the wheel.  “When the police tried to stop me, I hit a load of other cars and then ran away. “Going to prison was a lesaver. It’s not the holiday camp some claim it is. It was hard and made me take stock of my le.” Now Liam, , of Sandbanks, Dorset, runs his own chauffeur business and campaigns to reduce plastic waste in the sea.  His not-for-profit foundation Coacoara produces a range of plastic-free compostable products, such as carrier bags, sponges, cling film and toothbrushes. He is also the current British kite surfing champion. Liam, crowned Mr Dorset in , said: “I was over the moon about winning Mr England. It was humbling.  “I’d now like to do some work for a drink-drive charity, to show people there is a better way. “I hope it will give me the  to help promote my foundation and demonstrate to others that no matter who we are, we can achieve our dreams and goals.” Mr World will take place in Thailand next year, Covid restrictions depending. title: outsiders must wonder what happened
story: :root Outsiders must wonder what happened to UKs reputation of order and efficiencyThe Voice of the Mirror has questioned what has happened to Britains reputation under Boris Johnson, slamming the governments "incompetence and complacency"Motorists queue for petrol at Sainsburys at Monks Cross, York as drivers are being urged by the Government to buy fuel as normal, after the lorry driver shortage hit supplies Image: Peter HarbouropinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Sep | commentsAny outsider looking at Britain must wonder what happened to our reputation for being a nation of order and efficiency. A well-run country would not have queues at the fuel pumps, empty shelves in supermarkets and firms unable to source basic goods. Thanks to this Government’s incompetence and complacency, firms have been walloped by rising energy bills, a shortage of CO and a transportation crisis. And that is before you add in the disruption from Covid and economic pain caused by rising living costs. Boris Johnson has been in denial about the chaos caused by these multiple crises. An emergency is looming, but there has been no emergency planning. The Prime Minister likes to boast about Global Britain – but on his watch, we are in danger of becoming Broken Britain. Keir moment  Next week Keir Starmer will finally address the Labour conference in person. The pandemic has been doubly frustrating for the Labour leader, dominating the news, making it harder for the Opposition to be heard and preventing Sir Keir from properly introducing himself to the public. This why so much is riding on his leader’s speech this Wednesday. Sir Keir inherited a broken and ided party which had suffered its fourth election defeat in a row. Since then he has made steady,slow, progress in turning around Labour’s fortunes. The party is in a better place than it was two years ago, but Labour’s rehabilitation is not yet complete. That work must continue at the conference in Brighton. It is time the party stopped talking to itself and began a conversation about how Labour can transform lives and build a better Britain. MastERclass  Daniel Craig has revealed the Queen was a natural at acting when they made their  skit for the  Olympics. He was shaken and stirred by nerves, but she delivered a Royal Command Performance. news uk-news petrol-stations-closed-and-fuel-"BP announce petrol station forecourt closures in statementByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Sep | comments A national fuel shortage is causing petrol stations across the country to close, risking widespread disruption. The UK has been plagued by a number of shortages in recent weeks, brought on by a shortage of HGV drivers.BPaposs head of UK retail Hanna Hofer has said it is important the government understands the urgency of the situation, which she described as bad, very bad, ITV News reports.She added that BP had two-thirds of normal forecourt stock levels required for smooth operations and the level is declining rapidly. Here we take a look at which oil companies have faced petrol station closures, and the reason for the fuel shortage. Which petrol stations have closed   BP and Tesco have closed some petrol stations because of petrol and diesel supply issues, brought on by the lack of HGV drivers. There are around , BPO branded filling stations around the country, of which  are operated by BP themselves, and the oil giant has said a handful of these have been forced to close. The oil giant, which is the largest operator of petrol stations in the UK, has not said which specic ones have closed.  The Mirror reached out to BP, but the company could not confirm which specic petrol stations were closed due to the fast-changing situation. BP said in a statement: “We are experiencing some fuel supply issues at some of our retail sites in the UK and unfortunately have therefore seen a handful of sites temporarily close due to a lack of both unleaded and diesel grades. These have been caused by some delays in the supply chain which has been impacted by the industry-wide driver shortages across the UK and there are many actions being taken to address the issue. We continue to work with our haulier supplier to minimise any future disruption and to ensure efficient and effective deliveries to serve our customers.  They are currently working to address the problem, and prioritising deliveries to motorway service areas, major trunk roads and sites with the largest demands. The company said: We continue to work with our haulier supplier to minimise disruption and to ensure efficient and effective deliveries. Esso, which owns  Tesco Alliance sites, has reported similar issues with a small number of them. A spokesperson said: We are working closely with all parties in our distribution network to optimise supplies and minimise any inconvenience to customers. “We apologise to our customers for any inconvenience.” Currently these are the only two suppliers reporting shortages. Supermarket Morrisons has said itaposs not seeing similar issues with any of its  petrol stations, according to the BBC. Similarly, Co-Op, which operates  petrol stations, has a full complement of fuel delivery drivers. Tesco says it has a good availability of fuel, and the BBC report that both Sainsburyaposs and Asda have had no issues in fuel supplies. Why is there a fuel shortage   Is panic-buying understandable - or selfish  Let us know in the comments below Similarly to the food shortage which is causing empty supermarket shelves, the reason for the fuel shortage is to do disruption to the supply chain. This is due to a post-Brexit shortage in the number of HGV drivers. Since the UK left the European Union, many non-UK nationals who drive trucks have opted to work solely within EU countries. This has left logistics firms struggling to find workers. According to The Road Haulage Association , Britain needs as many as , more drivers to keep shops stocked and supplies moving.The coronavirus situation has made everything worse, with the closure of test centres worsening the shortage of drivers.The Department for Transport has recently changed the rules for tests to speed up the process of qualication.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BPExxon Mobil CorporationEuropean Union" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news petrol-stations-run-dry-drivers-"Cars queue up at petrol station in Bristol amid fuel crisisByTalia ShadwellReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsMassive queues are forming and tensions are flaring at petrol stations this morning as drivers flock for fuel despite pleas not to panic buy. Some UK service stations are rationing fuel as the lorry driver shortage hits petrol supply chains and forces forecourts up and down the country to shut. Worried drivers formed lines before the break of dawn in hopes of filling up, as scenes queuing stretched into a second day. Others were seen carrying jerry cans onto forecourts.At least one bust-up as been witnessed, as a clash broke out at a busy petrol station in Portsmouth, Hants, where drivers had flocked to a Shell station. Two groups of men were aposscreamingapos at each other before one group chased another fleeing in a van - hurling stones at the vehicle, according to a witness. The ugly scenes shocked onlookers at a forecourt in the Hilsea area of the city at around .am. A witness said: People were queuing throughout the night. Pumps are almost dry.Have you been affected by the shortage  Email your stories and pictures to webnews@mirror The man said the groups were screaming and shouting at each other. He added: One group got into their van and drove off out of the city as the other group gave chase and hurled stones at the retreating van. Itaposs utter madness. Lengthy queues were being spotted today around London, Essex and Kent to Bristol and Cambridgeshire, as industry bosses warned the capital and south of England were worst affected. Some petrol stations had road cones blocking forecourt lanes and signs announcing they were closed as pumps ran dry. Police forces are pleading with drivers to be apossensibleapos as lines were seen stretching around roundabouts in some parts of England. EG Group, which runs hundreds of forecourts across Britain, imposed a purchase limit of £ per customer for fuel due to the unprecedented customer demandaposapos.  Petrol retailers say they are unable to transport fuel due to a lack of lorry drivers, which is being blamed on Brexit labour shortages and the pandemic. Some firms have offered handsome cash incentives, salary increases and free training in desperate bids to recruit and retain drivers, as the exodus of EU workers left firms struggling to fill the gap. Reports have speculated the government is likely to bow shortly to industry demand to issue temporary migrant visas to plug the gaps.  Haulage industry bosses have warned the UK is short nearly , lorry drivers. The problem is being exacerbated by a gas price hike crisis threatening the UKaposs food supplies and driving up energy bills to eye-watering rates. Lincolnshire Police warned the queues could cause chaos on the roads and urged drivers not to fill upthey donapost need to. The force said: This is a potential hazard for vehicles making other journeys, and may cause dficulties for emergency services trying to reach people in need. While we appreciate that some people may be particularly keen to fill up their vehicles this weekend, we would respectfully ask motorists to be sensible when making judgements about joining a queue at a petrol station. If it is too long, consider ing at a dferent time. The president of the AA says panic-buying rather than supply chain issues is driving the shortage of fuel at some petrol stations.  Edmund King said the problem should pass in a matter of daysdrivers just stick to filling up when they need it, adding there is plenty of fuel at source. Speaking to BBC Breakfast, Mr King said shortage of lorry drivers had only been a localised problem earlier in the week. We were in discussions with Government ministers last night and we talked to the major fuel companies, and we can reiterate there is not a problem with supply at the source, Mr King said. Earlier in the week, there were some problems with the supply chain, as we know, due to a shortage of some lorry drivers, but that was only a localised problem.  Mr King warned the shortage had been exacerbated by people going out and filling up when they really donapost need to. If you think about it,  million cars out there,theyaposve all got half a tank they all rush out to fill up the rest of the tank and the tank is about  litres, that will put a strain on the system, he said. Mr King said the issues were unlikely to last because the supply chain is not being disrupted by ongoing problems such as industrial action. The good news is you can only really fill up once - youaposve got to use the fuel, so this should be a short-term thing, he said.  Itaposs not like the fuel crises in the past when the supplier was hit by strikes, etc. So, once people have filled up, they wonapost travel more than they normally travel, so this strain on the system should ease up in the next few days. However Mr King said the lorry driver shortage would remain an ongoing issue for the industry until solutions were found. Andrew Opie, director of food and sustainability at the British Retail Consortium, said: “HGV drivers are the glue which hold our supply chains together. “Without them, we are unable to move goods from farms to warehouses to shops. “Currently, the UK faces a shortfall of around , HGV drivers and it is consumers who ultimately suffer the consequences.” Comment MORE ON Panic-buyingVehiclesBPOn Instagram" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prince andrew finally concedes proper
story: :root Prince Andrew finally concedes proper service of legal papers in sexual assault lawsuitPrince Andrew is accused of forcing Virginia Gufre to have sex with him at several locations, including properties owned by late financier Jeffrey Epstein when she was a teenagerPrince Andrew has conceded proper service in the United States of a sexual assault lawsuit Image: REUTERSByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Prince Andrew has finally conceded proper service in the United States of a sexual assault lawsuit by accuser Virginia Gufre. The Duke of York is accused of having sex with her on three occasions when she was , knowing she had been trafficked by his close friend, the convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. Andrew and his accuser, now , jointly agreed that service was effective as of September , according to a Friday filing with the US District Court in Manhattan. The prince has until October  to respond to the lawsuit. He denies Giuffreaposs claims. A previously scheduled October  court hearing has been canceled.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  The agreement appears for now to end a monthlong effort by Andrewaposs legal team, including lawyers in Britain, to block Giuffreaposs lawsuit at the outset rather than have the -year-old defend against it. Giuffre accused Queen Elizabethaposs second son of forcing her to have sex around two decades ago at the London home of Epsteinaposs longtime associate Ghislaine Maxwell. She also said Andrew abused her at around the same time at Epsteinaposs mansion in Manhattan and on Epsteinaposs private island in the U.S. Virgin Islands.  Andrew has not been charged with crimes. His lawyers are seeking to review a  settlement agreement from a lawsuit against Epstein in Florida, to determine whether it requires a dismissal of Giuffreaposs August  lawsuit. Giuffre is seeking unspecied damages. Epstein, a registered sex offender, also had a home in Florida. He killed himself in a Manhattan jail in August  while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges. Giuffre sued Andrew under a  New York law that gave survivors of childhood sexual abuse a since-closed two-year window to sue their alleged abusers over conduct occurring many years or decades earlier. Maxwell faces a scheduled November  trial in Manhattan on charges she helped recruit and groom underage girls for Epstein to abuse. She has pleaded not guilty.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkUS District CourtRoyal FamilyJeffrey EpsteinGhislaine Maxwell" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-harrys-memoir-could-final-"Queen ready to forgive Meghan and Harry says punditBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsPrince Harry has been warned that further revelations could be the aposfinal strawapos for the anxious Royal Family.The Duke of Sussex, , is set to discuss Megxit and open up about the controversial switch to America after collaborating with a top American ghostwriter. The memoir is expected to hit the shelves next year - possibly around the time the Queen is celebrating her historic Diamond Jubilee. Harry said he is writing the book not as the prince I was born, but as the man I have become and stated that it will include the highs and the lows, the mistakes, the lessons learned. Buckingham Palace fear further explosive headlines as they pick up the pieces from Harry and Meghan Markleaposs tell-all Oprah interview. He has been secretly working on a memoir for nearly a year - and it has triggered a tsunami of fear among royal circles.But royal author and publisher Andrew Lownie believes Harry’s personal account could prove to be a step too far for the Firm.He told the Express that the memoir could sour Harryaposs already tricky relationship with his family.He said: “I think given the fact that he’s doing his tell-all book, I would have thought that’s the final straw for them.  The book will be published by Penguin Random House UK, with all proceeds to be donated to charity. Despite profits heading to good causes, two-thirds of Brits says they are aposnot interested at allapos in reading it. Over a third say it is aposinappropriateapos for him to publish it. A YouGov survey found says almost one in  people say he should not have signed the publishing agreement - and most wonapost read it.  In a statement confirming the book, the Duke said: Iaposm writing this not as the prince I was born but as the man I have become. “Iaposve worn many hats over the years, both literally and figuratively, and my hope is that in telling my story - the highs and lows, the mistakes, the lessons learned. I can help show that no matter where we come from, we have more in common than we think. “Iaposm deeply grateful for the opportunity to share what Iaposve learned over the course of my le so far and excited for people to read a firsthand account of my le thataposs accurate and wholly truthful.” But a source told the Daily Mirror the book has struck fear into the family. “Ever since leaving royal le, Harry and Meghan have made claim after claim of how they allege they have been treated, the insider explained. “They say that it is their truth but there is only ever one truth. “Since their interview with Oprah Winfrey tensions have been running very high as much of what they said has since been proven to be unreliable at best. “There is a now tsunami of fear among the royals over what Harry will write. title: residents flee homes middle night
story: :root Residents flee homes in middle of the night as properties begin to crack and sinkCracks began appearing in the walls and floors of peoples homes in Saltcoats, Ayrshire, causing residents to grab treasured possessions before fleeing their propertiesThe houses began to sink in the middle of the night Image: Daily RecordByMirror:,  Sep | commentsFamilies fled their collapsing homes in terror after they began to crumble in the middle of the night. Shocked neighbours found themselves scrambling for their lives in the dead of night after huge cracks began appearing in their walls. As they grabbed for treasured possessions the floor opened up beneath them, showing the earth below.Do you live on the road  Email webnews@mirror One person recalled the moment the homes began to crumble. It was so surreal, they said. It was like something out of a film. We just had to grab the essentials, the paperwork for the insurance and so on, and get out of there as quickly as we could. The cracks in the floor were getting bigger, it was literally crumbling underneath us. Itaposs heartbreaking. We donapost know what weaposve lost and what we will get back because we canapost get in to see. But we are grateful it was noticed when it was, because it could have been so much worse. Some residents of Saltcoats, Ayrshire suspect that the old coalmines beneath the properties are responsible for the issues. One resident noticed cracks had appeared on their walls when they woke up in the middle of the night - and raised the alarm with neighbours. The staircase of their upstairs villa flat later collapsed, with the back of the property sinking, while the ceiling of their downstairs neighbour caved in. Emergency service personnel arrived at the scene in the seaside town and told residents to get out of the unsafe homes. They evacuated  properties after the drama unfolded at around .am, the street was cordoned off and road ersions were put in place. Residents are staying with family and friends while repair work is carried out. A police officer at the scene told locals that foam concrete had been sprayed into the foundations and fixed the structure.  He said: Those houses wonapost move again. These guys are experts, they work all over the world. A Police Scotland spokesperson said: Several residents in Sharphill Road, Saltcoats, have been evacuated from their homes after we received reports of building safety concerns around .am on Saturday, September . Diversions are in place to allow further enquiries by the emergency services and partner agencies. The Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said they were no longer in attendance at the scene. The Coal Authority was contacted for comment. title: royal baby joy kate middletons
story: :root Royal baby joy as Kate Middletons close pal is pregnant days after Beatrice gives birthStarting as a Kensington Palace PA, stylist Natasha Archer has been working for the Duchess since  and it has now been revealed she is also pregnantKate Middleton is celebrating news that her close friend Natasha Archer is pregnant Image: Getty Images for LTAByEllie CookEstel Farell-Roig:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA close friend of Kate Middleton is pregnant, it has been revealed - just days after Princess Beatrice gave birth to her first child.Earlier this week, Prince William and Kate congratulated Princess Beatrice, , on the birth of her first child with husband Edoardo Mappelli Mozzi, .Buckingham Palace announced the birth last Monday , with the baby girl weighing lb oz and being born last Saturday. And it has now been disclosed that Kate aposs stylist Natasha Archer - who has been working for the Duchess since  - is also pregnant, as reported by the Express. However, she has not always been her stylist and began as a Kensington Palace PA before adding styling responsibilities to her job description, according to Grazia magazine. A royal source told Grazia last year: ‘Natasha and Kate get on very well. “She has always supported and advised Kate – and the duchess loves Natasha’s style, so it seemed like an obvious appointment.” Also known as ‘Tash,’ Ms Archer is married to a royal photographer. Ms Archer’s pregnancy announcement is not the first for herself and her husband, Chris Jackson.  According to HELLO! magazine, the couple welcomed a son, Theo, in . It is now known that two more of the Duchess’s staff will be going on maternity leave at the same time.At present, the Palace is advertising for several roles on the Duke and Duchess of Cambridgeaposs personal staff, according to reports. These include a deputy personal secretary as well as a maternity cover for a personal assistant for the Duke and Duchess.  The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge don’t currently have any plans for another child, according to royal expert and Daily Mail diary editor Richard Eden. He said: “Catherine won’t be having a fourth child of her own,Wills can help it. “When a well-wisher suggested the prospect in , she replied: ‘I think William would be a little worriedapos.”Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror Earlier this week, Prince William and Kate congratulated Princess Beatrice, , on the birth of her first child with husband Edoardo Mappelli Mozzi, . Buckingham Palace announced the birth last Monday , with the baby girl weighing lb oz and being born last Saturday.The baby’s name is yet to be revealed, but it is known that she will inherit the title of ‘Nobile Donna’ from her father. The title translates to ‘Noble Woman’ in English. She was born at the Cha and Westminster Hospital in London last Saturday. title: sabina nessa how men can
story: :root Sabina Nessa: How men can help women feel safer while walking alone at nightThe murder of Sabina Nessa, six months after the death of Sarah Everard, has once again thrown the topic of womens safety walking the streets of UK towns to the forefront of conversation Image: REUTERSByAndrea Oldereide:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  In the course of less than a month, two high-profile cases of women being murdered have sparked debates on how society can better womenaposs safety – the recent murder of American YouTuber Gabby Petito and of British school teacher Sabina Nessa. Femicide, the killing of a girl or woman, is a topic that has already been highlighted earlier this year, when Sarah Everard, a -year-old marketing executive, was killed in South London, on her walk back home. These victims tragically add to a horrying statistic that has been recently reported: six women are killed every hour by men around the world, according to UN data. Additionally, a woman is killed by a man every three days in the UK. According to Karen Ingala Smith, co-founder of the Femicide Census, men’s violence against women is a leading cause of the premature death for women globally but research in the UK and Europe is limited and unconnected. Dr Nilufar Ahmed who works as a Behavioural Psychologist at the University of Bristol helped us identy things men can do to help women feel safer and ways to stop violence towards women. How men can help feel women feel safer while walking alone  Being taught consent from a young age Men should learn to accept a womanaposs lack of interest in them. Violence inflicted on women is often entangled with sexual assaults, and therefore should be educated on consent. According to the United Nations Women , freely given and enthusiastic consent should be mandatory, “every time”. UN Women added that phrases like “she was asking for it” or “boys will be boys” attempt to blur the lines around sexual consent, placing blame on victims, and “excusing perpetrators from the crimes they have committed”.  Dr Nilufar Ahmed explained to the Mirror that changing our social attitudes was something that needed to happen across society and from an early age. She said: Understanding consent from an early age. ‘No means no’ is often framed in terms of sexual consent and rape, but it has a much bigger application –someone is rejecting your attention, friendship, or company in any setting, respect this. Schools can play a role in this by teaching young children about respecting boundaries. Being taught gender equality in schools The World Health Organisationpublished a pamphlet revealing that gender inequalities increase the risk of violence by men against women and inhibit the ability of those affected to seek protection. Experts have found that exposing children to non-stereotypical characters found in books and movies, as well as iding housework equally at home, can help children understand the notion that all genders are equal. Stop victim blaming Victim blaming is a way for someone to justy their motivation behind their own crime, while literally blaming their victim for their own action. Too often the behaviour and personalities of the women is scrutinised and judged first before the actions of the man who attacked them. Dr Nilufar Ahmed told The Mirror. She added: As though it is inevitable that a lone woman walking in the dark is automatically at risk of being attacked.  This victim blaming exonerates men from responsibility and blame by focusing on the woman. Allied with this, often when men commit heinous crimes, their crimes are qualied with added information about their lives as ‘good fathers’ or ‘high achieving students’, whilst the women are described only in terms of the way they were dressed and their actions that night. Becoming a better ally to women Doing something as simple as listening to women and their experiences goes a long way. Men should be able to acknowledge their privilege, as well as taking women’s concerns as a serious issue. Furthermore, men should not shy away from calling out blatant sexism and misogynistic behaviour when they witness it. Being supportive and contributing to the safety of women starts by becoming an ally. Destigmatise men’s mental health As the WHO found that potential perpetrators may be at an increased risk of committing femicidethey are unemployed, own a firearm, have made previous threats to kill with a weapon, or have committed sexual violence, men’s mental health needs to be addressed. Saying things like “man up” or “boys don’t cry” nourishes a culture of toxic masculinity which both prevents men from expressing their feelings, but also lead to dangerous behaviour such as resulting in violence instead of communication. According to Dr Nilufar Ahmed, there is not one reason that pushes men to harm and kill women, but it can include psychological reasons such as feeling rejected, feeling incapable of attracting a partner, being angry, feeling emasculated, a need to assert control, feeling entitled. These do not necessarily have to be about women – a man may experience repeated rejection from jobs, be angry at their landlord, etc, She said. She continued: Unaddressed, this can boil over and be projected onto a target that men are stronger than – women. Most men experiencing these will not go on to harm women butthese feelings are overwhelming go unresolved they can be damaging to the inidual and others around them, and could in extreme circumstances lead to aggression and even murder. If men are struggling with any of these issues accessing mental health support can help to work through them. Facilitate women’s access to protection and safety against domestic violence The WHO has revealed that there is an increased risk of perpetuating femicidethe aggressor has a history of intimate partner or family violence. A men with a history of domestic violence thereby is more likely to murder his partner. Domestic violence is reportedly not taken seriously in UK courts, as criminologist Jane Monkton-Smith toldthat her examination of  domestic abuse killings shows how sentences for manslaughter convictions were often mitigated by “ridiculous claims, like how much the perpetrator said they loved the victim”. Immediate things men can do to help according to a psychologist Dr Nilufar Ahmed said: Immediate things men can do are to be mindful to keep a safe distance from women when out walking or running. If you see a situation where a woman looks uncomfortable don’t be afraid to intervene either yourself or by making someone  aware .As a society we must all take responsibility for collective behaviours and actions. This means calling out comments and behaviour that are disrespectful to women whenever we encounter them.
