news uk-news sabina-nessa-latest-new-cctv-"Sabina Nessa: CCTV footage released of man Met police are seekingByTalia ShadwellReporter:,  Sep  Detectives investigating the murder of schoolteacher Sabina Nessa have released CCTV video footage of a man urgently being sought by police.Scotland Yard footage and moving CCTV still captures of the man which show him walking in Pegler Square in Kidbrooke, south-east London, on the evening the -year-old was attacked. A -second clip shows a balding man wearing a black hooded coat and grey jeans looking over his shoulder and pulling at his hood as he walks down a path. The Met spokesperson told the Mirror earlier today the force was not speculating about the appearance of the manaposs hands or reports of how Sabina may have been killed. Earlier today reports claim police sources believe she was pounced upon and attacked with a hammer just moments after leaving her flat on what should have been a five-minute walk across a park to her pub date.  Detectives have also released an image, captured in the Pegler Square area of Kidbrooke, of a silver car they believe the man has access to. The Met has appealed for anyone who recognised either to contact the force immediately. Detective chief inspector Neil John, from the Metaposs Specialist Crime Command, said an extensive trawl of CCTV in the area continued and said information on the manaposs identity and whereabouts could be vital to the investigation. Sabina was walking to meet a date at The Depot bar in Pegler Square near her home at around .pm last Friday when she was attacked.  A member of the public found her body under a pile of leaves close to the OneSpace community centre in Cator Park, in the borough of Greenwich, on Saturday at around .pm. The politan Police said a -year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of Sabinaaposs murder. The suspect was arrested at an address in Lewisham on Thursday and is being questioned in custody. It is the second arrest Scotland Yard has made in connection with the attack. On Saturday, detectives arrested a man in his s on suspicion of murder before he was released under further investigation.  Ms Nessaaposs cousin Zubel Ahmed remembered her as a beautul soul who loved teaching, telling the BBC that she was the most caring person - kindest, sweetest girl you could meet. Lisa Williams, the head of Rushey Green Primary School where Ms Nessa taught, said staff and pupils are taking our time to reflect and process the devastating news of her death and will be remembering the teacher privately. In a statement, Mrs Williams said: We have shared the details about the vigil with our school community and some people may be attending on a personal level to privately pay their respects.  As a school we are taking our time to reflect and process the devastating news we received this week, and will be commemorating Sabina in our own way. The vigil is being held on Friday evening at pm at Pegler Square, and people who cannot attend are being encouraged to hold a candle at their doorstep at the same time. Reclaim These Streets, a campaign group involved in supporting the Kidbrooke communityaposs vigil for Sabina, said it is angry and heartbroken about her murder. Tower Hamlets Councillor Rabina Khan told BBC Radio aposs Today programme said she was attending the vigil this evening and hoped high profile people would also attend. I too, just like my daughters, I have a -year-old, I have a -year-old, we spoke up for Sarah Everard, she said. When we saw high profile people who attended , I was really pleased and proud that the Duchess of Cambridge attended the vigil... I hope, tonight, we see many profiled people attending Sabina Nessaaposs vigil.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Scotland Yardpolitan PoliceCCTVMurderCCTV footageSabina Nessa" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sabina nessa man seen hiding
story: :root Sabina Nessa: Man seen hiding object up sleeve must be traced over murder, say copsThe politan Police is appealing for help in finding a balding man shown on CCTV walking in Kidbrooke, south-east London - in the area where the primary school teacher was heading on the evening she diedPolice want to speak to this man Image: Met PoliceByHelen WilliamRyan HooperLaura Parnaby:,  Sep A man being hunted over the murder of teacher Sabina Nessa must be traced, police have said - as they release footage of him potentially hiding an object up his sleeve. The Met is appealing for help in finding a balding man shown on CCTV walking through Pegler Square in Kidbrooke, south-east London - the area where the primary school teacher was heading on the evening she died. The force released the video on Friday and said the man is believed to have been carrying a reflective red object. DCI Neil John, from the Met’s Specialist Crime Command, said the man, pictured wearing a black hooded jacket and grey jeans, may have been trying to hide the object up his sleeve.  He said: “I continue to appeal for any witnesses and anyone with information to contact police and share what they know. “People in the Kidbrooke area last Friday may recall seeing this man carrying a red reflective object, and possibly trying to conceal it up his sleeve. If so, please call police. “Please share the CCTV footage on social media and, especiallyyou have connections to London or Kent, show the image to family members and friends who may not have seen it. He must be traced. “We all saw at yesterday evening’s vigil the impact that Sabina’s death has had on the community. “I would reiterate my plea to those in the local area to think andyou have any information that could help this investigation, then please get in touch.”  Hundreds of mourners, including tearful relatives, gathered for an emotional candlelit vigil in memory of Ms Nessa on Friday. Jebina Yasmin Islam, her sister, broke down as she addressed crowds at the vigil. She said: “I just want to say thank you to everyone who came today to show support for my sister. “We have lost an amazing, caring, beautul sister, who left this world far too early.” She added: “Sabina loved her family.  “Words cannot describe how we are feeling, this feels like we are stuck in a bad dream and can’t get out of it – our world is shattered, we are simply lost for words. “No family should go through what we are going through.” Ms Nessa’s uncle Shahin Miah described his niece as “a kind and a open-minded person”, who was “always smiling and helping others”. He said Ms Nessa’s death has “once again brought to the fore the question of women’s safety on the streets”. In his statement, he said: “We don’t want what happened to Sabina to happen to anyone .  “We don’t want any other mother’s chest to be empty or filled with deep sorrow, or to see the tears in the eyes of any father.”The Duchess of Cambridge also described how she was “saddened by the loss of another innocent young woman on our streets” on Twitter.OneSpace community centre, which is close to where a dog walker discovered Ms Nessa’s body a week ago, invited members of the community to write tributes to her in a book of condolence as it re-opened on Saturday. The building had been cordoned off by police as they searched the surrounding Cator Park where officers believe Ms Nessa was attacked, and it remained closed until the weekend as a “mark of respect”, the owners said. Ms Nessa had been walking to meet a friend at a pub near her home when she was attacked in Cator Park on September . Her body was discovered by a member of the public the next day, having been hidden under a pile of leaves, it was reported. Two men were separately arrested on suspicion of her murder but were subsequently released under investigation. Detectives also circulated an image, captured in the same area, of a silver car they believe the man they are searching for had access to and appealed for anyone who recognised either to contact the force immediately. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information at www.mirror email . news uk-news sabina-nessas-family-shocked-brutal-"-year-old Margaret Keenan gets her Covid- booster vaccineByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep The family of primary school teacher Sabina Nessa have said they are shocked by her brutal murder and are still struggling to understand how she did not make it home safely. Ms Nessa, , was taking a five-minute walk to meet a friend at The Depot bar in Pegler Square near her home in Kidbrooke, south-east London, on September  at around .pm when she was attacked. A member of the public found her body close to the OneSpace community centre in Cator Park on Saturday at around .pm. A -year-old man arrested in connection with the murder has been released under investigation, the politan Police said today.  The man was arrested on Thursday at an address in Lewisham, south-east London, and detectives are continuing to appeal for information about another man captured on CCTV in Pegler Square on the evening Ms Nessa was attacked. In a statement released to the PA news agency ahead of a rally at the East London Mosque, her sister Jebina Yasmin Islam said: We as a family are shocked of the murder of our sister, daughter and aunty to my girls. There are no words to describe how we are feeling as a family at the moment. We did not expect that something likewould ever happen to us. I urge everyone to walk on busy streets when walking home from work, school or a friendaposs homes. Please keep safe.  I ask you to pray for our sister and make duafor her. May Allahgrant her paradise. Halima Begum, chief executive of the Runnymede Trust race equality think tank, told PA: Speaking as a woman and a Londoner from the cityaposs Bangladeshi community, Iaposm heartbroken. Sabina is related to members of my extended family and everything I know about her speaks of a beautul, intelligent young woman who had so much le to live, and so, so much to offer in terms of making a positive dference to the peopleaposs lives she touched, not least her familyaposs and the young children she taught at school. Tragically, gender-based violence does not occur in isolation. I do not know how many more women will suffer before our streets are safe. What I do know is that Sabinaaposs death fills all of us with grief. Londoners, regardless of their gender, are hopeful that Sabinaaposs murderer will be found and brought to justice swtly.  Community leaders and Asian women, some of whom said they were too wary to attend a vigil for Ms Nessa on Friday night in south-east London but still wanted to show their solidarity in a location they feel safe, are among those who are gathering at the mosque. Fridayaposs events in memory of Ms Nessa come a week after she died and as the public spotlight is thrown on womenaposs safety and gender-based violence. Her death comes after the public outrage and protests over the abduction and murder of -year-old marketing executive Sarah Everard as she walked home alone in south London in March. Sufia Alam, of the East London Mosque and the Maryam Centre, said: This brutal murder of one of our shining stars is genuinely saddening and deeply shocking. I have three daughters, and I canapost even begin to express what I am feeling right now. Sarah Everard was one of our daughters, and so was Sabina Nessa - their lives were tragically cut short - at the hands of violence and brutality. We have much work to do against the violence faced by women in our society. We will not stop campaigning until our mothers, sisters and daughters are safe anywhere and everywhere. She said this state of affairs is not just about women and girls being vulnerable, this is about men and boys and educating them early on about respecting and honouring women and girls, and treating them with the dignity they deserve. Ms Alam, who is set to be at the east London rally where many women are due to attend, added: When a Muslim woman is murdered, this dampens the aspirations of other Muslim women and girls in education and employment - and this will be particularly hard for us to deal with and manage.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON House of CommonsMurderCrimePoliticsHate crimeSabina Nessa" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news sabina-nessa-six-unanswered-questions-"Sabina Nessa vigil: Crowds gather in Kidbrooke to pay tributeByTalia ShadwellReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep The public is being urged to share CCTV images of a mystery man and a silver car in hopes of bringing schoolteacher Sabina Nessaaposs killer to justice. Scotland Yard is appealing for help as detectives work around the clock to solve the -year-oldaposs murder in south London. Sabinaaposs death has led to widespread grief and amplied concerns about womenaposs safety after she was killed as she was about to set out on what should have been a five-minute walk. Sabina had left her Kidbrooke home to make the short journey across a park to a pub to meet a date at around .pm Friday when she vanished. A dog walker discovered her body under a pile of leaves at a park the following day. Sabina was described as “beautul, talented and caring” by her grieving sister. Pals said the talented young woman had dreams of moving abroad to teach in Dubai.  Where did she vanish  Detectives say Sabina, a teacher at the Rushey Green Primary School in Lewisham, set out on what would have been a five-minute journey to meet a friend at a pub in Kidbrooke Village, south London, at around .pm Friday. Her short journey would have taken her about  minutes from her Astell Rd home across Cator Park to get to The Depot in Pegler Square. Pals have said she was excited about going on a date with an old friend that evening at the bar. But she never arrived. Sabina was not reported missing by anyone after failing to show up to the bar. Adog walker found her body near a walkway close to the OneSpace community centre in Cator Park, Kidbrooke, in the Royal Borough of Greenwich at around .pm Saturday, under a pile of leaves. Police have not yet said publicly at what point of the journey she is believed to have been attacked.  What was the cause of death  A post-mortem carried out at Greenwich Mortuary proved to be inconclusive, police said on Monday. Detectives have said they believe she was hit with a heavy object and was taken to Cator Park, where her body was found. A Met Police spokesman said the force is not commenting on the reporting on the suspected murder weapon.Who killed her Police have said they were keeping an open mind on a motive to the killing, which has been widely reported as a suspected stranger attack Speaking at the scene where tributes had been laid to Sabina next to the police cordon at Cator Park on Thursday, Detective Chief Superintendent Trevor Lawry said earlier he is “keeping a completely open mind” on what the motive of the attacker may have been.  Asked whether detectives were worried the killer could attack someone , he said: “We have lines of inquiry that we’re pursuing at the moment. “It’s always a concern that it may happen, but that’s not something that we have any intelligence on at this time.” Asked whether he believed the killing was a stranger attack, DCI Lawry told reporters:“That’s definitely a line of inquiry that we’re looking at.” Sabinaaposs flatmate, speaking on condition of anonymity, told reporters she feels unsafe after losing her friend. Her fearful housemate of four months said she had last seen Sabina when the pair hung out and took pictures together.She told: ‘I never thought something like this could happen to her. I had been texting her and it’s not like her to not reply to my messages.“I don’t feel safe living here now.”  Who is the man in the CCTV images  Police say CCTV images of a man seen walking through south London is another person they would like to speak to. The force says the unknown man was in the area at the time of the attack, as well as pictures of a silver car they believe he has access to. The images of the man, taken from CCTV, shows him walking in Pegler Square, south London, on the evening Sabina was attacked. Where is the mystery car captured on CCTV going  Police have also released an image of the car they believe the man has access to, which was also captured in the Pegler Square area. Police are urging anyone who recognises the man and vehicle to make contact immediately. They have not revealed any more detail yet about exactly where or when the car was seen or what direction it was heading. However they have said they are appealing for sightings of the man and car across the south London borough of Greenwich, including in Catford, Kidbrooke and Greenwich itself. Have arrests been made  A man in his s was arrested on suspicion of murder at an address in Lewisham on Saturday evening, and was later released under police investigation. The politan Police announced on Thursday that a second, -year-old man had been arrested at an address in Lewisham on suspicion of Sabinaaposs murder and was being held in custody.  What you can you to help Police want to speak to anyone who may have seen anything that could help their investigation. Anyone who recognises the man in the CCTV images or has seen him in recent days is being urged to contact the Met. Detective Chief Inspector Neil John, from the Metaposs Specialist Crime Command, said: Our team have been working tirelessly to find the person responsible for Sabinaaposs murder and this has included an extensive trawl of CCTV, work which remains ongoing. We would ask anyone - especially those in Kidbrooke and the wider area of Lewisham and Greenwich - to take a careful look at these images to check whether you know who this man is or have seen him over recent days. Any information as to his identity or whereabouts could be vital for our investigation so we are asking you to share this image far and wide to ensure as many people as possible see it.  Where to attend the vigil for Sabina Nessa Vigils are being held for Sabina in locations around London later on Friday, and people are being encouraged to light candles on their doorsteps. Reclaim the Streets, a campaign group calling for an end to male violence against women, involved in organising previous vigils, said it is “angry and heartbroken” about her murder. Sabinaaposs death comes after the killings of Sarah Everard, who was knidnapped and murdered by a Met cop as she walked home, and sisters Bibaa Henry, Nicole Smallman, who were stabbed to death in a park. ‘I don’t feel safe living here now.’ Sabinaaposs community of Kidbrooke in Greenwich have organised a vigil at pm on Friday evening in Pegler Square, with the support of Reclaim these Streets. The vigil will be held to remember Sabina, how she lived and the lives she transformed as campaigners demand womenaposs rights to safety, the campaign group says. Anyone with information on the Sabina Ness case should call the Met Police incident room on    or Crimestoppers completely anonymously on   .Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Sabina NessaMurderCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: spider expert explains what you
story: :root Spider expert explains what you should always do when you see daddy long legsKarl Curtis, from the Warwickshire Wildle Trust, has explained why we shouldnt kill daddy long legs even though so many people are scared by themA spider expert has revealed what to doyou see Daddy Long Legs Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMorgan JohnsonEstel Farell-Roig:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsDespite being so common, many people have a fear of spiders and therefore dread this time of the year - spider season. So many of us have done some research into how we can get rid of them and, for instance, bought plants that help keep them away as a result.While they are actually a type of crane fly according to the Wildle Trust, daddy long legs are often incorrectly believed to be spiders because of their long legs.And an expert has now explained why we shouldnapost kill daddy long legs even though so many people are scared by them. Although slightly annoying, this type of crane fly is completely harmless and doesnapost bite like some spiders, as reported by CoventryLive.Karl Curtis, director of reserves and community engagement at Warwickshire Wildle Trust, said: They are out this time of year because basically, they are hatching out of our lawns and ious places - they live a lot of their lives underground as a grub, as a larva, and then what they do is they hatch out over the summer. Probably now is the last throw of the dice, and what they do is they come out and looking to mate, lay eggs back into vegetation and then they die off.  He added: They often get confused with spiders but theyaposre not, theyaposre flies, theyaposre really good food source for birds, theyaposre really important to play their part so people should let them out their windows and not kill them. Mr Curtis also said that things like fly sprays are bad for the environment and other living things so should be avoided. And he noted that crane flies are in fact not poisonous, contrary to popular belief and shouldnapost be feared. What do you think about this story  Sign in and let us know in the comments below  He argued they have probably got a reputation for being poisonous as people mistakenly think they are cellar spiders. The very long spindly spiders that you get in the corners of your room, theyaposre called cellar spiders, those do pack a punch, but they are not dangerous to humans, he said. [Crane flies] theyaposre absolutely harmless. While the female has a point on the end of her abdomen, thataposs to lay eggs, itaposs not a stinger.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirrorHe went on: The reason they come into the house is for warmth and they are attracted to light sothe lights are on in the house they come inside, and they hatch out in the darker hours to avoid being eaten by birds. Theyaposre not looking for shelter, theyaposre out looking for a mate and then looking to lay eggs, they end up in houses because their favourite habitat is short grass and we have lawns. The wall-jumping insect helps get rid of spiders, aphids, dead insects, fungus, bird droppings, worms and snails. title: terrifying hgv driver experience leaves
story: :root Exclusive: Terrying HGV driver experience leaves Mirror man keen to stick to day jobAs the UK gets desperate for truck drivers the Mirror sends a reporter to have a go - and its nowhere near as easy as you might think, with our man keen to stick to his normal workTrucking hell: Our Dan was not a fan Image: STAN KUJAWAByGraeme CullordDan Hall:,  Sep | commentsThe Sunday Mirror sent reporter Dan Hall to try his hand at driving an HGV – amid reports of drivers being tempted with £, salaries and fears rookie drivers will be a danger on the roads. Dan headed to the National Driving Centre in Croydon, South London, where trainees can drive trucks of up to  tons and . metres. And our man admitted: “It was terrying. We’re only driving around a quiet car park, but the stress of being in control of such a massive vehicle with other cars, people and buildings around is enough to make me glad we’re not out on the road. “When I set off going backwards in the NCA’s articulated lorry, I’m a shambles, struggling to keep the lorry straight.  “Even crawling is an overwhelming exercise in concentration. “I managed to inch the lorry into the bay but I’m horried to see how close I am to the barrier. I think it’s saferI stick to my day job.” Dan’s experience came as firms are trying to fill , vacancies. The Government today sets out a visa scheme allowing , foreign truckers to work in the UK temporarily. And the Department of Transport has simplied HGV testing in a bid to fast-track , lorry-driving rookies into jobs before Christmas. For example, reversing exercises have been cut from the main test as a time-saver. Kate Gibbs, of the Road Haulage Association, said: “Safety has to be paramount. It’s inevitable accidents will happen and we have to do all we can to make sure that that doesn’t happen.”  Victoria Lebrec lost her left leg when she was knocked off her bicycle by an HGV in . Now head of policy at the RoadPeace campaign group, Victoria, , warned: “More people will be killed and seriously injuredroad safety is compromised. “This feels like something that has been rushed through in reaction to an economic issue and I’m worried it has not been properly considered.” Laurence Bolton, of the National Driving Centre, said it was “a huge ask” to expect ordinary drivers to master lorry driving without proper experience. title: texting deceased loved one softens
story: :root Texting a deceased loved one "softens the harsh reality" says psychologistWhile before it may have been listening to an old answer phone message, now this modern coping mechanism is a new comfort for the bereavedHave you ever sent a text to a deceased loved one  Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Sep | commentsLosing someone close to us can be extremely dficult - and many of us have dferent ways of coping with the grief. It’s important to note that everyone copes with grief in dferent ways, and there is no real right or wrong in the grieving process.With digital reminders of your loved one on social media s like Facebook and Instagram, things can get really tough. Although there are ways to turn off the profiles, you may still miss their online presence and knowing that they are a short message away for a quick chat.Reopening old text messages are bound to bring up many emotions, but what about those who continue to text their loved one  It’s now a common coping mechanism, and experts say it can actually be useful for those to deal with the transition. When considering why many people do this to cope with their loss, psychologist Ingrid Collins said: “When a loved one dies, we find it hard to adjust immediately to the fact that they are no longer physically with us. “In the first stages of grief, we tend to become emotionally numb as a result of the trauma of bereavement, often finding it dficult to accept that they are really gone.”FRisk is a wakeup call for the millions of people with no will or protection in place for their own death. FRisk is a FREE intuitive app that produces a FRisk Score confirming the level of risk your family and loved ones face were you to die without effective planning in place. Use Frisk to find out your own personal FRisk Score including: What would happen to your children  Who’s entitled to your estate  Who can bring claims  How much tax would you pay  What about your pets and your digital estate  Plus much more. Get your FREE FRisk Score now by clicking here. It is in this phase that many find it comforting to ease adjustment to a loss by continuing on a conversation. Ingrid continued: “Be it imaginary, as some believe, or communicating with the lingering soul of the loved one, as others believe. “Either way, it is a way of softening the harsh reality of never being in their physical presence again.  As a culture, it’s no doubt that we are taught to cope well with bereavement, with a “stf upper lip” approach for many. To some, that may signy that the inidual may not be coping well at all, and bottling up any emotions from others. When talking about text messaging loved ones that have passed away, Ingrid said: “Any method that enables us to prolong the comfort of the relationship with the deceased or,the bond was challenging, to go some way to resolving the relationship, is to be welcomed. “Sometimes people cling on to their loved one’s physical possessions that serve as a reminder. “This is one way of adjusting. Some take up a campaign in order to bring some meaning to what might otherwise appear to be a random or supposedly preventable death.” In short, those who choose to communicate with a deceased person are “taking an effective shortcut to arriving at some measure of acceptance.” Comment MORE ON GrievingText messagesFrisk" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news two-britains-worst-fly-tippers-"Footages shows extent of fly tipping in NewportByChiara Fiorillo:,  Sep | commentsTwo of Britainaposs worst fly-tippers have been caught on camera while dumping rubbish on deserted roads. Bradley Lynn, , and Connor Williams, , have been filmed carrying stacks of waste to leave at deserted roadsides. Environment chiefs launched an investigation to find the fly-tippers after they used fake number plates to carry out the crimes. CCTV footage shows Lynn and Williams apparently travelling in an untaxed and unregistered tipper van. The pair were spotted dumping rubbish at a former LG site in Newport, South Wales, in September and October last year. The site has been dubbed the Road to Nowhere as it has become a hotspot for fly-tipping.  Lynn, of Splott, Cardf, and Williams, of Trowbridge, pleaded guilty to an offence under the Environmental Protection Act . Magistrates in Newport fined each man £ and ordered them to pay costs of £, and a victimaposs surcharge of £. Newport city council said it worked with Gwent Police and Fly Tipping Action Wales to bring them to court.  After the case, Councillor Roger Jeavons said: I would like to thank the public for providing information that led to the identication of these two people. As well as fines, they could have faced being sent to prison for this crime and I hope this prosecution will act as a deterrent to others who illicitly dump waste. Residents should also note thatthey employ others to clear waste and itaposs not disposed of legally then they would also be liable and could be prosecuted.  We will not hesitate to take action against those who deliberately dump refuse on our land. It is a crime that blights our communities, the city and our environment and it will not be tolerated. title: uk weather autumn truly arrives
story: :root UK weather: Autumn truly arrives next week with hail and thunder to batter Brits“Hail and thunder is also a risk to the North and West, so Monday heralds a real change towards the autumnal-style weather" says Met Office spokesmanThunder and hail could hit parts of the country next week Image: PAByKaren RockettJournalist:,  Sep | commentsMake the most of the summery weather today... because it looks like autumn arrives tomorrow. The September mini-heatwave is due to give way to something much colder and ­wetter, with hail and thunder even predicted in some parts of the UK on Monday. Most of us have enjoyed glorious sunrises recently, like the one in Baldersdale, Co Durham , yesterday. But don’t get used to them.BBC weather forecaster Matt Taylor said: “If you’re wondering where autumn is, it’s not far away. Wait until we get to mid-week, next week – a big change. Temperatures are going to drop.” They could fall as low as C in Inverness, which is enjoying temperatures in the high teens this weekend. And while London will bask in C today, it will be wet tomorrow and thermometers will only reach about C.Nicola Maxey, at the Met Office, said a cold front will cross the UK from East to West on Monday bringing ­“potentially heavy rain”.She added: “Hail and thunder is also a risk to the North and West, so Monday heralds a real change to autumnal-style weather.” Met Meteorologist Adam Thornhill said the change is due to “a sht in the position of the jet stream”. ■ An ash cloud from the La Palma volcano has grounded flights to and from the Spanish island. Airport operator Aena said that plane traffic has been suspended “due to the accumulation of ash” in the air following the eruption, which started last Sunday.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeSailingWeatherSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uk weather forecast britain sizzle
story: :root UK weather forecast: Britain to sizzle in glorious C mini heatwave this weekendThe Met Office predicts that temperatures up to C could be experienced on Saturday as Brits are set to enjoy a sizzling weekend before the weather then cools down from MondayThe UK will see high temperatures up to C this weekend - meaning many will flock to beachesByDouglas Patient:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe UK will see high temperatures up to C this weekend with an Indian summer predicted for the next two days.The Met Office has said London and the South East could see maximum temperatures of C on Saturday, with both days having bright and sunny spells.Some pockets of England, just north of London, could also see highs of C or C. Sunday will be slightly cloudier but the temperature will otherwise remain around C in most places. The western parts of England and the whole of Wales could see some cloud and potential rain on Saturday morning before it brightens up in the afternoon with highs of C.  This could take a turn on Sunday with some heavy showers in the South East. North-western Scotland meanwhile will be windy in the morning on Saturday before becoming a mainly dry day with some bright or sunny spells developing and highs of C. Sunday will be largely dry and bright with strong southerly winds around the coast. The weather will take a turn on Monday, with the Met Office predicting next week to be the start of autumnal weather.It comes as people have been warned by the AA to not top up their cars outside of their normal routines ahead of planning any potential weekend trips away to take advantage of the weather. Nicky Maxey, for the Met Office, said: Youaposre much more likely to see highs of  degrees more widely but we could see some spots reaching highs of  or C.  It will be similar on Sunday, with places such as Lincolnshire potentially seeing similar temperatures, but still the higher temperatures being in isolated pockets rather than widespread. She added: Sunday perhaps will see an increased chance of rain, but thereaposs still plenty of sunny spells around and fine weather. But we have got a cold front moving in to Northern Ireland and Scotland on Sunday and then crossing from east to west of the UK on Monday. Thataposs bringing some potentially heavy rain. Thereaposs still some sunshine scattered round on Monday but we could see heavier showers. Hail and thunder is also a risk to the North and West, so Monday heralds a real change towards the autumnal-style weather. Weather forecast for Saturday: Starting rather cloudy with occasional drizzle or rain in the west, especially northwestern Scotland where it will also become increasingly windy. Some sunny intervals likely where. Very warm in sunshine. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Still warm for many on Sunday, some heavy showers in the South East. Rain and stronger winds arriving into the west starting a change to cooler, unsettled conditions early next week. title: unjabbed ex page 3 girl
story: :root Exclusive: Unjabbed ex-page  girl nearly died twice after Covid hit her like a truckHolly McGuire, , was a self-confessed anti-vaxxer who thought Covid would not affect her - until contracting the disease left her in hospital for six weeks clinging to leHolly McGuire was floored by CovidByPhil CardySenior reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA former page  girl who backed the anti-vax movement has told how she almost died after ­catching Covid. Holly McGuire, , was put into an induced coma and given just a % chance of survival after contracting the virus. She needed a tube inserted into her windpipe to help her breath and spent six weeks in hospital fighting for her le. Now she is urging everyone of all ages to get the jab, saying: “It could save your le. Never take le for granted. This can happen to anyone – including you. “I was an anti-vaxxer, I was ­unvaccinated. Now I can honestly tell people Covid is real.  “Please, everyone, ignore the nonsense some people are spouting, get the jab. “Luckily for me I have lived to tell my story. But I nearly died twice. “My husband Steve was told to prepare for the worst. He phoned my mum in tears saying it didn’t look like I would make it.” Holly, who appeared in the TV series Footballers Wives in , said she battled double pneumonia and her lung collapsed while she was in hospital.She spent two weeks in a coma, missing her daughter Madison’s ­seventh birthday, and due to breathing ­dficulties caused by the coronavirus she also had a tracheotomy. What do you think of this story  Join the debate in our comments  Holly, from Grays, Essex, but now living in Marbella, Spain, said: “I have a healthy diet, don’t party, hardly drink and don’t smoke. I thought, ‘This disease won’t affect me’. “A lot of my friends were anti-vaxxers, campaigning against the jab, and I was listening to them, too. “People were saying we won’t know for yearsthe jab is reliable and seeing news reports from back home I didn’t feel reassured by the UK Government. “I thought there were so many reasons not to have it. “I now regret that so much. I made so many excuses not to have it, but when I caught Covid it was dreadful, it hit me like a truck. Just get vaccinated as soon as possible.” Holly tested ­positive for Covid on July  and spent  days isolating at home. But she started having breathing dficulties and was admitted to intensive care in a Spanish hospital. She developed pneumonia in both lungs. Doctors struggled to bring her out of the coma fearing she could lose her le. When Holly did wake up she had lost two and a half stone and was struggling to use her legs, needing intense physio to help her walk again. She said: “I was in hospital for six weeks in total and I am so grateful to still be here. “I’ve felt shattered ever since. Last weekend was the first time I’ve been out with my family. “I was an anti-vaxxer but now I know I was wrong. I never thought I’d get Covid, but it can hit anyone.” Comment MORE ON Holly McguireHospitalsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: we deserve certain minimum teacher
story: :root We all deserve a certain minimum - teacher reveals sad incident that opened her eyes to hygiene povertyBoots and charity The Hygiene Bank are working together to stop pupils going without the basics - heres how you can helpAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Sep Contending with fidgety, distracted children is standard practice for teachers. But it was the reason why one particular child couldn’t focus that changed everything for deputy head-teacher Rebekah Wilson.“A boy in my class didn’t seem his normal happy self and he couldn’t concentrate for scratching his stomach,” says -year-old Rebekah, known as Bex. “He told me he didn’t have a bed at home, and the cushion he shared with his brother to sleep on was infested with bed bugs.”This was the moment that Bex, who works at an inner city primary school in Leeds, realised the impact that hygiene could have on her pupils and their education. “Times are hard for some families who are having to choose what they can do without,” she says. “Hygiene items often get sacriced. We’re not talking luxuries here, just the absolute basics like toilet roll, shampoo, deodorant, shower gel and soap. “Going without these things affects kids’ self-esteem. Imagine what it’s likeyou can’t keep yourself clean or you don’t have clean clothes  It can really stop children learning, engaging and taking part at school and it can lead to bullying or them being singled out.” Happily there’s an organisation that’s helping to relieve the pressure. The Hygiene Bank, which stresses that being clean is a basic human right, collects new, unused, in-date personal care and household cleaning essentials and distributes them to families in need through schools like Bex’s and charities.  And Boots has been supporting The Hygiene Bank by hosting more than  banks in stores across the UK where customers can donate their own hygiene products. The retailer then donates four products for every kilogram that has been donated. Toothbrushes and toothpaste are two items Bex knows are particularly needed. “So many children are coming to school with tooth problems now,” she says. “Bad dental health can cause a lot of pain and distress and really affect children’s confidence.” But something as simple as shampoo or shower gel can also improve the wellbeing and happiness of those struggling to stay afloat. “I had a mum in tears the other day because we’d given her a hygiene package that included some shower gel. As little as a p bottle can make a dference. She said it felt like Christmas.” Another mum had just £ left for her weekly shopping. “She needed nappies, washing powder and washing up liquid. She didn’t know what to buy because she knew she couldn’t get it all.” Hygiene products provided through The Hygiene Bank across the UK help fill the gap. “We all deserve a certain minimum,” says Bex. “We need to ensure every family has access to these basics, and remove the stigma of asking for support, making sure that families are treated with respect.” Boots leads big donation drive Boots and charity The Hygiene Bank are working together to provide much-needed hygiene and personal care products to people living in poverty.  In the last year, Boots, which has more than  donation points in stores across the UK, has given more than , items – from toothpaste to shower gel, soap to shampoo – to hundreds of communities and charities across the UK. Boots donates hygiene products to The Hygiene Bank. And since it believes every child has the right to feel good when they go back to school, Boots has also worked with the charity to design educational resources for parents and teachers to help young people understand hygiene and hygiene poverty. In its ‘You donate  we donate’ initiative, Boots gives four products for every kilogram of items donated to The Hygiene Bank in Boots stores.You can donate at your local Boots donation point, through the boots e-voucher scheme, and directly to The Hygiene Bank. Products are distributed to those who need them via schools, charities, council services and voluntary organisations. Milford on Sea Boots Store Manager Charlotte Whiteside says: “We’re very grateful for anything that our kind-hearted customers donate – but essentials include shampoo, toothpaste and sanitary products.” Shampoo Deodorant Toilet roll Period products Toothpaste Toothbrush Soap Nappies

news uk-news why-stormed-good-morning-britain-"GMB: Richard Madeley criticises activist over M protestopinionByLiam Norton:,  Sep | comments On Wednesday I appeared on Good Morning Britain. It all got a bit heated.I was prepared to be called a hypocrite, a fascist and to be asked why I don’t go to China to be shot at . I’ve been managing quite well during the last few weeks to stay calm during the barrage of questions that have been coming my way. People have been quite rightly furious and upset by what we are doing and I accept that. What frustrated me on Wednesday was the refusal by the other people on the programme to accept the physical reality we are in. The reality that Sir David King means when he says, “What we do in the next three to four years will determine the future of humanity”. That’s the reason I’m on the telly sitting through that rage and anger. It is because I really care about the country I live in and all the people who live here. Do you agree with Insulate Britainaposs actions  Have your say in the comments below  What the GMB presenters are not ready to accept is that climate breakdown isn’t primarily about survival of polar bears and dolphins, as important as they are, but about the survival of our economy, our NHS and of the very fabric of our society. This means many people will suffer.  What Insulate Britainis asking for is to conserve our society. To do that at this time means having to make some tough decisions, we understand that. The comparisons to Churchill on the programme upset Richard Madeley. I wasn’t saying that IB were the same as Churchill, what I was saying was that there were some similarities. The people that didn’t want to oppose Hitler were seen as appeasing Hitler. Churchill understood that you either faced up to the reality now or you paid for it later. He had the support of just six MPs. That meant that  million people lost their lives. It was locked in. There is a similarity now. If we don’t move as rapidly as Sir David King says we should, the suffering of millions of people in the next few decades will be locked in, unstoppable. What was happening on GMB on Wednesday was appeasement. A refusal to accept the reality, while also turning their anger of that reality onto me. Well we feel angry too. Angry that our government has ignored our letters, petitions and protests for  years.Insulating our homes is our line in the sand and we will not let them cross it. It gives the best value for money in terms of CO emissions, will provide hundreds of thousands of meaningful jobs and will stop tens of thousands of our elderly from freezing to death each winter and means families can heat and eat. This isnapost aboutmy home is insulated or not. Itaposs not about whether Iaposm a hypocrite for calling for all homes to be insulated. Itaposs about how tackling the climate crisis will not only save our country from destruction, but also benefit millions of our citizens and bring them out of fuel poverty. Itaposs a win-win. What Richard and Susanna don’t seem to understand is thatthe government continues to ignore us, it will get much more heated. title: woman 22 followed grabbed men
story: :root Woman, , followed, grabbed by men while walking home in London day and nightTalisker Cornford, , founder of womens safety group Urban Angels, said she is harassed by men while walking home in London several times a weekTalisker Cornford said she is harassed multiple times a week Image: MyLondon WSByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA womenaposs safety campaigner said she faces harassment from men at least three times a week while walking home. Talisker Cornford, founder of group Urban Angels, described how she has been grabbed and followed at all times of day while alone in London.“Sometimes itaposs subtle, she told My London. And sometimes itaposs very explicit.“Iaposve had people try and stop and talk to me a lot or try grabbing my arm and talking to me. Just being very persistent. Day and night. People shouting things at you, following you, I feel like thereaposs too many examples.” The -year-old, who set up the initiative in March in the wake of the Sarah Everard case, has seen it quickly grow to a worldwide community. She started it with a friend while studying in Exeter and similar groups were quickly launched in Birmingham, Cardf, Portsmouth and Brighton.Have you been affected by this story  Let us know at webnews@mirror  Talisker is in the process of setting up groups across London and next week one goes live in Amsterdam. Plans are also in the works for a Toronto version of Urban Angels. The group is used for alerts, discussions about safety measures, and many cities now have walking schemes to pair up people walking in the same direction late at night. She was speaking in light of the murder of Sabina Nessa, who was found dead in Kidbrooke, south-east London, on Saturday morning.The -year-old school teacher had been walking a short distance to the pub from her home the night before when she was attacked. It comes as Transport for London said it has no plans for theof the Night Tube until next year after the Covid pandemic saw the service halted. The   train service operated on Fridays and Saturdays for the Victoria, Jubilee and most of the Piccadilly, Central and Northern lines.It means night buses, taxis or walking are often the only means of transport home after dark. “Itaposs not a good move. In terms of womenaposs safety and safety for non-binary people,” said Talisker of the decision to hold off on reintroducing the service.  “I really want the Night Tube back. Andy Lord, managing director of the London Underground, said: “We are playing, and will continue to play, our full role in London’s recovery from the pandemic. We are running as close to a full service as possible across all our services and the Tube continues to serve Central London with last trains leaving around : and starting again at :. Our extensive night bus network continues to operate. We are continuing to review our options for when we might be able to reintroduce the full Friday and Saturday Night Tube in a safe and viable way and are exploring the feasibility of reintroducing some services on one or two lines more quickly.” Talisker believes people might feel safer using the Night Tube rather than the night buses which still operate across London but can be a minefield. “One of the big things for safety that a lot of people always say is familiarity, she said. If you donapost know where you are, you’re instantly less safe, because you kind of donapost understand which routes you are taking, youaposre potentially going to be out for longer or later.” The campaigner went on to say Tubes are in areas more densely populated and often staffed. news uk-news woman--can-blow-out-"Woman blows out candles through eye socket after eyeball removedByRia Newman:,  Sep | commentsA woman can blow out candles through her eye socket after having her eyeball removed due to a rare deadly cancer. Emma Cousins, , from Sheffield, has been living with one eye after being diagnosed with mesenchymal chondrosarcoma in April . She had noticed her left eye appearing to grow and bulge and shortly after her daughteraposs second birthday she went to AE to get checked out as she started to feel unwell. Emma, who is mum to an -year-old son and five-year-old daughter, said: “My eye felt stretched and I felt sick. “The doctor thought it was a small bleed so I saw an out of hours optician who askedI had any selfies on my phone.  “I had six years’ worth of pictures so I showed the optician, who asked to see pictures of me from further back. “It was at that point I thought ‘oh no something is wrong’. I managed to find pictures of me at . “The optician said he didn’t know for sure but that it looked like something had been growing behind my eye since I was .” Looking at the images side-by-side, Emma could see a subtle dference as her eye appeared to grow and bulge over time. She was booked in for an MRI scan which found a large tumour growing behind her eye and in April  a biopsy was taken to seeit could be salvaged.  Sadly, nothing could be done and she was diagnosed with a form of sarcoma cancer – and told she would lose her eye. Emma said: “I thought ‘no, it can’t be, I’m too young’ and the doctor was acting very nervous. “The doctor said ‘the eye will have to come out’ and told me I’m the only person in England with it, and that chemotherapy wouldn’t work.“He told me not to Google it but obviously that was the first thing I did when I was alone.“I wish I had listened as all I could find were pages saying it spreads to the lungs and you die. “After reading that it made me panic and the reality kicked in – I was going to lose my eye and I had cancer.” Over the following weeks, surgeons planned the tricky, warning Emma that, while they would remove as much of the tumour as possible, she would be left disfigured. Emma said: “I had to tell my children because, with my eye going, I couldn’t hide it from them. “I told them I needed to have my eye removed then I would be better.” In June , she had her eyeball removed in a terrying procedure. Emma said: “I was nervous but knowing I had cancer and how bad it could be made me feel better about it. “Losing an eye for a chance of saving my le was a risk I was willing to take. “I think one of the worst things was  minutes before the eye removal, one of the nurses drew an arrow on my forehead to highlight which eye it was – and for the rest of my time left with two eyes I was panicking they would take the wrong eye out by mistake. “My main concern was what would happen with the kids – my daughter was so young at the time, so she wouldn’t remember anything about me.” Thankfully, Emma made it through the tough surgery and started a six-week course of radiation therapy, which caused burns to her skin. Sadly, she had a reaction to the treatment and ended up in ICU connected to a ventilator as she fought off the debilitating symptoms linked to fulminant multiple sclerosis, which left her “completely paralysed”. She said: “I couldn’t even talk – it was like being completely locked in my own body, unable to communicate anything. “Doctors told my family I would die, but to their surprise I regained the ability to talk, my arms started to work, and I have slowly recovered to the point I can now walk myself – although not as well as I used to.”  Her medics were left equally baffled by the adverse reaction and much is still unclear about why Emma suffered so much post-surgery. As soon as she saw herself with one eye, Emma realised she looked “dferent to anybody ”. She said: “The first thing I can remember thinking was ‘wow it doesn’t look as bad as I thought’. “It was still a few months before it all settled and the bruising had gone down, but it looked so much nicer than I had presumed it would look. “I actually liked it because everything has been done now with hair and makeup, whereas everyone notices how dferent I look – and I try to live up to that with my eye patches. “After all, they are going to stare at me anyway, so why not give them something to stare at ” Later that month in June , Emma was referred to have a prosthetic eye made, but found it to look “fake” and be too much “faff”, so opted instead to wear glasses and eye patches. Over time, a small hole developed in her empty socket – which doctors believe was caused by the radiation – that has been widened. Emma said: “Because the radiation has killed veins in my socket they supply the skin with blood and because blood cannot get to the area the skin dies and that’s what the hole is. “I’ve waited over a year for the operation but now the hole is getting bigger simple things like having a shower or being in heavy rain can drown me. “As the hole is directly connected to my lungs – meaning anything going in my eye can enter my lungs. “I have to stay away from a swimming pool and baths as I could drown.” Her children have been incredibly supportive, as Emma explained: “They have been wonderful. When the hole first appeared to now, they have had to see it grow in size but have been great at adapting – even though it has meant no swimming, which they love. “I don’t think they realise just how good they have been throughout all of this. “They have had to grow up so fast and seen daily not only how big the hole is getting, but my daily struggle to recover.” Despite her suffering, she has received global attention on TikTok, after taking to the social media  to share videos of her empty socket. One video received  million views, with thousands of fans cheering her on. One person said: I would just like to say this is not scary but inspiring, unique and beautul. Because this is who you are. This is so powerful, another fan added. Someone  commented: No offence but it kinda looks like your eye is breathing but your beautul. [sic] Emma also showed off her unique party tricks – which include blowing out candles with the hole in her socket. Now, the mum is focusing on continuing her recovery, which should involve a procedure taking a chunk of skin from her leg to cover the hole in her eye socket. title: woman extreme ocd cant leave
story: :root Woman with extreme OCD cant leave her room and takes  minutes to brush teethEXCLUSIVE: Vanessa Ward, from County Down in Northern Ireland, has been in solitary confinement for the past decade and feels she is "being assassinated every minute of every hour by OCD"Vanessa Ward in her room. At the time this picture was taken, she had spent  hours straight trying to catch a small fly in her bedroom with a hoover Image: Vanessa WardByEstel Farell-Roig:,  Sep | commentsA woman suffering with severe OCD has opened up about what le is like for her. Vanessa Ward doesnapost leave her bedroom and has been in solitary confinement for the past decade, with the simplest of tasks such as brushing her teeth taking her  minutes.The -year-old has said she feels like an empty vessel and that she is being assassinated every minute of every hour by OCD , describing the disorder as an endless stream of constant torture. Ms Ward, from Castlewellan in County Down, Northern Ireland, said she has always suffered with OCD but was able to have a semblance of a normal le up until  years ago. Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror She said: For the past decade, however, my le is now dictated solely by OCD - I have no le outside of it. I have lost my twenties to this debilitating illness. I have been in solitary confinement for  years and I havenapost left my bedroom. My days are spent between a bedroom and an en-suite and I have become totally isolated from all close friends and family. I am totally alone because of it and have nearly died from the isolation and loneliness OCD brings more than once. Ms Ward - who is now trying to raise funds for a specialist treatment - wrote on her GoFundMe page that her movements are now so complex and calculated that she is like in a catatonic state.I have set rules and complex rituals that must be carried out in a systematic, orderly and symmetrical way, she continued. If I donapost do this the thoughts, anxiety, nausea and terror are so much of a punishment I have no option but to comply. I do these rituals all day, every day to the point I faint on a very regular basis. I have stopped eating for weeks and on three occasions my family have had no option but have me admitted to acute mental health hospitals. On the second admission, my health was so critical that I was sectioned under the mental health act.Ms Ward - who is one of five siblings - said that her mental health has led to a deterioration in her physical health as well, going from  stone to nine stone within a year as a result of the anti-psychotic drugs that were tried during a hospital admission.She also has changes in her eyesight and suffers from hair loss and fractured teeth, together with deficiencies in potassium, folic acid, and vitamin D. While most adults having a resting heart rate between  and bpm, Ms Ward said hers is around bpm. I never get a break from the constant torture and thoughts of OCD, she continued. I can go for periods of  hours with no sleepOCD dictates it. My le has been so miserable - I have just been existing and I feel like an empty vessel. After several admissions to acute hospitals where no one could help me I just felt like dying - I wanted to die. Death is easier than this endless stream of constant torture and feeling like I am being assassinated every minute of every hour by OCD. I wanted euthanasia almost daily but my family kept trying to tell me it will get better.  Ms Wardaposs sister Priscilla said that, as a family, they can see the endless ways OCD has ruined her le. The -year-old said her sister is isolated from the outside world - with no personal relationships or any friendships - and can no longer do the simplest of things. Ms Ward now lives in a house on her own, she explained, with family members visiting her every day to bring her food and encourage her to eat.  The eldest sister said: She has been sick for so long she is now hyper sensitive to sounds and smells. A simple smoke alarm gives her an anxiety attack to the level she feels she would take a heart attack. There is no enjoyment in her le anymore and she has nothing to look forward to. She is a prisoner in her own mind. She is also painfully aware how absurd her behaviours and rituals are but OCD always over rides this and she must comply. Ms Ward said her sisteraposs OCD is a never ending cycle of floods of thoughts that cause endless anxiety and,the ritual isnapost completed, the thoughts and anxiety wonapost stop.  As the years have gone on, these rituals have become longer and more complex, she continued, to the point her sister now spends every hour of every day carrying these out. Ms Ward said her sister is crippled and completely disabled by OCD now, adding the picture of her in the bedroom was taken as she spent  hours straight trying to catch a small fly in her bedroom with the hoover. This was without a break, drink of water or sleep, she continued. Complete adrenaline caused by fear keeps this going. We, as a family, canapost even help in a scenario like this becausewe enter the bedroom we have now contaminated it and she would have to do endless streams of rituals to the point were she would be so exhausted and weak she would be fainting. We constantly feel useless, guilty, worried, hopeless, powerless and heart broken. The sister said her mum thinks Vanessa was born with OCD, not wanting to be touched or cuddled since she was a baby. Ms Ward said the OCDaposs symptoms started to accentuate when her sister was a teenager, for instance taking six hours to have a shower. Planning on an IT career, Ms Ward said her sister has only ever had a couple of summer jobs in between school years. She added: We canapost remember the last time we gave Vanessa a hug, gave her a gt, celebrated her birthday, heard her genuinely laugh or that contagious smile and care free attitude she had. Our Christmases now are opening presents without her, not having her at the dinner. We are all together while she has been sitting alone in a room or sitting in a mental health hospital listening to other patients screaming. A family gatherings or weddings, again we have the guilt and sadness that she isnapost there and is alone suffering endlessly. When wider family members inevitably ask how she is, we are all fighting back tears and the happiest of days are always tainted with sadness. She isnapost able to be with us but her tortured face is everywhere we look.  The family is now trying to raise funds for specialist treatment with a world-renowned professor in OCD which would involve staying at a private hospital for at least six months, working daily with professionals carrying out Cognitive Behavioural Therapyand Exposure And Response Prevention . Ms Ward wrote on the GoFundMe page: I had given up all hope until my family came across a world renowned Professor in OCD. They arranged a consultation with him online. He stated that my case is quite the challenge and I was waiting for the inevitable aposI donapost think I can help youapos but to my astonishment, do you know what he said to me  aposVanessa donapost give up hope because I can help youapos. I can not tell you how that felt. I just started crying uncontrollably. I couldnapost even comprehend it. I couldnapost believe it. After years of  hope and constant let downs, he can help me. The Professor has dictated that treatment needs to be started imminently as my condition will continue to plummet. What do you think about this story  Sign in and let us know in the comments below Ms Ward - who hopes to become an ambassador for OCD in the future - has so far been able to raise more than £, but her goal is £,. Her family hopes that the specialist treatment will teach Ms Ward coping mechanisms and tools to manage her OCD, said Priscilla, teaching her to notice for signs of relapse so she can prevent any further deterioration. She added: Medications at present will help to change the chemistry in the brain, but the ERP and CBT will help to change the structural pathways in her brain and how the neuro transmitters communicate. This is the last resort for Vanessa to try and get help, for her to be pulled from the never ending sea of sadness she is drowning in. title: women dying hands men horrific
story: :root Women are dying at hands of men at horric rate of  a week - I am numb with fearYet again, women across the country are asking questions about their security in the wake of the murder of Sabina Nessa as she walked alone to meet a friendSabina Nessa died on the evening of September  Image: politan PoliceopinionBySaira Khan:,  Sep Are our streets safe  Yet again, women across the country are asking that question in the wake of the murder of a young woman as she walked alone to meet a friend. Sabina Nessa, a -year-old teacher, is thought to have been taking a five-minute route through a park at around .pm on a Friday. She did not make it. Her body was found by a passer-by the next day, hidden under a pile of leaves in Cator Park, South East London – just a stone’s throw from her home. Friends and relatives describe Sabina as a beautul soul who was always caring and kind. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan said this week that between last year’s International Women’s Day and this year’s,  women in Britain were killed at the hands of men. He warned: We do have an epidemic when it comes to violence against women and girls. As a woman and a mother, I am numb with fear. My first instinct was to promote the importance of personal safety to other women.  I posted a list of the  best apps for women walking alone at night, I reminded women to be vigilant, not to bury their heads in their phones or walk around with earphones in. But that is to ignore the real issue. We do all this as routine – simply because we are women, and we are dying at the hands of men at the horric rate of three a week. It is abhorrent that, because of my gender, I can’t walk the streets with the same confidence a man can. It is abhorrent that I have to put an app on my phone to ensure my husband knows I’m safe. It is abhorrent I have to take my alarm. And it is abhorrent that,it is dark, I feel anxious by myself. ThatI see a man walking towards me I feel vulnerable – so I clutch my bag, quicken my pace and cross the road. Why should I feel like that  Why should any woman have to  So many parents have dropped their daughters off at university this week, my niece being one of them. My sister-in-law gave her the talk all parents of daughters will know: Keep your drink with you so no one spikes it, don’t go anywhere without your phone, always stick together, don’t walk alone and please, please, text me so I know you’re safe. And that was before we heard about Sabina Nessa’s murder. I’m sure that will have led to many frantic texts begging to please be careful, stay safe, don’t walk travel by yourself at night. I don’t want to be repeating all this to my daughter when she goes to university in eight years. I want there to have been signicant changes in how women are treated, so they do not fear for their safety. Some % of women say they feel unsafe or very unsafe walking alone at night in their local area. Just % of men express the same concern. For me, the single biggest change we need is the education of young men on women’s rights, on what misogyny looks and sounds like, on what equality really means. Men have a vital role in combating this. They need to know they can call it out, prevent it and stop it. How the Met Police can claim that London streets are safe beggars belief. They will only be safe when men stop attacking women – and when women can walk without fear.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Murder" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news us-news famous-tv-host-run-after-"Inés Gómez Mont proposes to Tom Brady at Super Bowl in ByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA famous TV host is on the run after embezzling billions of pesos from Mexicoaposs Ministry of the Interior. Mexican officials have urged Interpol to track down Inés Gómez Mont and her lawyer husband - Víctor Manuel Ález Puga.The couple are accused of embezzling almost  billion pesosfrom the government ministry between  and , according to Uno TV via People.Ms Gómez Mont is most famously known for proposing to celebrity quarterback Tom Brady while dressed in a bridal gown. Ms Gómez Mont and her husband are said to have entered the United States after a warrant was issued for their arrest on September , local media reports. Ms Gómez Mont and her husband are said to have entered the United States after a warrant was issued for their arrest on September , local media reports.On Instagram she has accused authorities of not providing access to that warrant, nor the proof that justies it.She added theyaposre preparing to face this process and exercise all our rights. The couple are both facing y prison sentences of  to  yearscaught. The TV star is known for turning up at a Patriots-Giants Super Bowl press conference in  to tell then-Patriots quarterback Tom Brady that she loved him.  Brady rejected the woman dressed in full wedding garb - excusing himself due to a relationship to then-girlfriend Gisele Bundchen. The footballer and Bundchen were married in February , a month after their engagement. The spurned presenter moved on quickly to Giants quarterback Eli Manning with a T-shirt reading, Marry Me Manning. Local news reported that Mexicoaposs Attorney Generalaposs Office has requested Interpol issue international capture warrants for the couple. Interpolaposs red notices allow dferent countries to track them as they move around the world. title: inside eerie abandoned water park
story: :root Inside eerie abandoned water park that shut down nearly  years agoThe Lake Dolores Waterpark in Calornia is in a dilapidated state after its permanent closure in , but it is now up for sale for  million The Lake Dolores Waterpark in Calornia had a rocky history including three re-opening and subsequent closures Image: Jam Press Raise the Stakes PhotographyByRia NewmanEstel Farell-Roig:,  Sep " data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _PAY-Eerie-photos-show-state-of-famous-waterpark-abandoned--years-ago-as-site-is-listed-for-M.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top"" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _PAY-Eerie-photos-show-state-of-famous-waterpark-abandoned--years-ago-as-site-is-listed-for-M.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top"" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _PAY-Eerie-photos-show-state-of-famous-waterpark-abandoned--years-ago-as-site-is-listed-for-M.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsEerie photographs of an abandoned waterpark which has laid dormant in the desert for nearly  years have been shared - after the site was listed for  million.Earlier this month, photographer Shaun decided to visit the Lake Dolores Waterpark in Calornia, US, after hearing reports of the sale. The abandoned park - which featured in US television shows including Top Gear America - is currently in a dilapidated state following its permanent closure in .This came after a rocky history including a serious accident that led to a former-employee becoming paralysed, together with three re-opening and subsequent closures.  Seventeen years after it was abandoned, the current state of the former family favourite has been captured in the photographs taken by Shaun, who described the abandoned waterpark as an incredibly surreal scene. In one image, the entrance to the dilapidated park can be seen almost entirely covered in graffiti – a theme which continues through the site, having clearly been frequented by visitors since its closure. In another shot, litter can be seen scattered across the grounds – including what appear to be spray paint cans. What do you think about this story  Sign in and let us know in the comments below  Meanwhile, nature has started to take over the abandoned site, with overgrown trees throughout the park. In an aerial shot, the barren land surrounding the park can be seen – stretching out into the distance. A crumbling slide can be seen in the background of one image, curling around a hill and covered in dirt. Many of the park’s slides were sold years ago, leaving large empty spaces in the once-bustling park.  “I’ve visited the park several times over the years since it was first abandoned, and each time it is slightly more decayed and weather-beaten – not to mention covered in spray paint,” Shaun, who is in his s and lives in northern Nevada, told Jam Press. “This particular visit was in mid-September  after Iaposd heard the property was listed for sale for  million – which kind of seemed like a joke, as it is so damaged itaposs hard to imagine making any al use of the structures and remains of the old waterpark that are still standing.  The Raise the Stakes Photographyaposs owner added: “A large waterpark sitting abandoned in the arid Mojave Desert is an incredibly surreal scene, and itaposs great to see people turn it into essentially a playground and guerrilla art gallery for those others who are willing to hop the fence and explore it. “The state of decay is part of the whole thing, and knowing it wonapost exist forever – whether it becomes some fancy development like the owner is hoping for with listing it for sale, or eventually just reverts to massive lot of sand like much of the other parcels out here – just makes it something to appreciateyou can catch it the window of time that it exists in this state.”  The -acre park is located in the Mojave Desert and was built by local businessman Bob Byers, who named it after his we, Dolores, opening to the public in . Nicknamed the ‘fun spot of the desert’, in its heyday it was chock full of waterslides, zip lines, a lazy river, bumper boats and a go kart track. It closed in the s due to legal and financial problems, later reopening as Rock-a-Hoola Waterpark in , but a year later an accident involving an off-duty employee led to a law suit and a . million judgement against the park.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror The employee had slid into an inadequately filled pool and was paralysed from their injuries. Investors declared bankruptcy, leading to the park’s second closure. Finally, it was reopened in  as Discovery Waterpark – but closed permanently in , leaving many of its structures to crumble, though most of the park’s slides were sold to other waterparks. Now, the formerly popular site is for sale with Samina Mahmud at a listing price of  million – and includes permission to develop the property for any commercial use. It was last sold in  for . million. news us-news meghan-markle-given-new-nickname-"Meghan Markle says it is wonderful to be back in New YorkByJenner Newton:,  Sep | comments From the Duchess of Sussex to Meg, it seems like Meghan Markle goes by a number of names. And it appears that another moniker can be added to that list after she was given a new nickname during her appearance in New York yesterday.Meghan, along with Prince Harry, were at the One World Observatory in the city, on what was their first public appearance since moving to the U.S after stepping down as senior royals.During the visit, they met with New York City mayor Bill de Blasio, his we Chirlane McCray, their son, Dante and New York governor Kathy Hochul and posed for pictures with them. During the photocall, one reporter called out to Meghan to ask her how she was enjoying her trip to the Big Apple. But rather than call her Meghan, he referred to her as Madam Duchess. He said: Madam Duchess, are you enjoying your visit to New York  And Meghan replied: Itaposs wonderful to be back, thank you. Video shows Harry then turning to Meghan grinning and he appears to mouth aposMadam Duchessapos at her before they continue to pose for the cameras.Taking to Twitter, one fan wrote: Look from here on out it is Madame Duchess for me with #MeghanMarkle.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .Another said: Who besides me is really liking the title Madame Duchess Meghan  While another added: YASSSS! Madame Duchess Meghan Markle it is. Following their morning meeting at the One World Observatory, Meghan and Harry went to the   Memorial and Museum. Later they met with the US ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield. Writing on Twitter, the ambassador said they had an “important discussion” that included talking about the pandemic, racial justice and raising awareness of mental health.Tomorrow, they will appear at the -hour star-studded global TV event Global Citizen Live on the Great Lawn in Central Park.At the event, they will continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the Covid- pandemic for everyone, everywhere. The event organisers call them two of the strongest voices on vaccine equity.
